title: Omicron cause mild symptoms jabbed elderly people according super spreader party
story: Share this article While the event may demonstrate the generally mild symptoms of Omicron it also demonstrates how potential infectious Omicron can be.Professor Spector reported that all guests had been vaccinated and 10 of the guests infected had received their Covid booster.Omicron is believed to be partly more infectious because of its 30 plus mutations compared to the original Covid strain, meaning antibodies in vaccinated iniduals, and those with prior Covid infection, are less likely to recognise the new variant.     While boosters have been shown to provide greater protection against Omicron it is not clear if the two people who did not catch Covid at the party were among those who got their third Covid jab.Professor Spector also told The Guardian that he was advising people to stay at home and away from parties if they had cold-like symptoms and also wear high-quality masks on their way to a venue.  'Avoid large gatherings and split your groups up into smaller ones where you can control the environment and get everyone to test that day,' he said.'Make sure that no one attending that party has cold-like symptoms, or hasn’t had cold-like symptoms the past three or four days, and on the way to the event make sure that you’re wearing a high-quality mask on crowded public transport, which people are not doing.'The party was held in a house where guests shared lunch, with 14 of the infected over 60-years-old. Reports on the supposed mildness of Omicron come as Boris Johnson confirmed today that at least one person has died of the variant here in the UK.News of the death came hand-in-hand with chaos in Britain's attempts to both track Covid cases and fulfill the Prime Minister's new pledge to dish out a million boosters per day to beat the super-mutant variant. Speaking during a visit to a vaccination clinic in Paddington, west London, Mr Johnson did not reveal the age of the person who died, or if they had underlying health conditions, which made them vulnerable to Covid. Some 10 people infected with the variant are in hospital, health chiefs said. Britain's youngest patient is 18 years old, while the oldest is 85. The majority are double-vaccinated, but officials would not reveal whether any had also had a booster jab. It came as vital stocks of lateral flow tests ran out after ministers called on Britons to take one before meeting family this Christmas. A message on the Government website says there are 'no more home test kits available right now' and tells Britons to 'try again later'. A spokesman insisted there was no shortage, but said 'exceptionally high' demand meant they had stopped taking new orders while existing ones were completed. They said the kits could still be picked up from community sites including pharmacies, schools and colleges, and that PCR swabs are available. In another sign of chaos, Britons desperate to get their top-up doses were left standing in up to five-hour queues as centres warned they were already running low on doses this morning. Twenty-somethings were turned away in confusion at Manchester City's Etihad Stadium as they tried to get booster jabs.Meanwhile, the NHS booking system crashed as thousands tried to secure a booster, with health service bosses urging people to 'try again tomorrow'. How Omicron appears to be infecting Britain – despite the vaccine | Coronavirus | The GuardianOmicron 'may only cause cold-like symptoms even in elderly - as long as they're vaccinated'

story: Now 24 veterans will, of course, remember their version of Lionel Richie’s Easy, complete with “Ugh!” Chelsea v Lille. As you were!Sporting v Man City. Great trip and Super Bock beer, difficult game. Salzburg v Bayern, and Chelsea breathe a sigh of relief. With the semis and final to take place, F1-style, in Qatar, Saudi and Abu Dhabi.For that, I will gladly spend tomorrow writing another blog suffused with official intervention. Any excuse. But yup, he was still brilliant, just not as brilliant.  And these are the group runners-up and therefore unseeded teams, who’ll play the first leg at home: Teams from the same country cannot face one another and teams who qualified from the same group cannot face one another. First legs will be played on 15162223 February, with second legs played on 891516 March. The away goals rule no longer applies, so if aggregate scores are level after 180 minutes, extra time will be played, and if they remain level are 210 minutes, penalties will be taken.On the too many penalties point, they need to change the laws. Denial of a goalscoring opportunity anywhere on the pitch, penalty foul or handball in the box but no goalscoring opportunity, direct free-kick.  “External service provider” though, you’ve got to laugh. Did the “external service provider” decide to plough on with the draw when everyone could see it wasn’t fair as well? Michael Meagher: “Granted there should be an embargo on this song ever being played anywhere for at least a decade. However, waaaaay better than the Jeff Buckley version: Kevin Dwyer: “Divine Comedy covering My Lovely Horse at Electric Picnic.” Iain Pearson: “Bob Dylan got a shout-out for his Clash cover, so how about I Fought the Law as a banging cover of a banging original?” Police and Thieves ismy favourite of theirs, but this also approved. Giles Skerry and Martin Constantinides: That is an absolutely befuddling thought, given how good he still was, but yup, I’ve heard that from elsewhere – though I didn’t see him play for PSV. Er, OK then, just me. But what a tie that is for Celtic, nothing better than a trip somewhere you’d likely never go otherwise, and watching your players freeze to boot. Rapid Wien v Spurs or Vitesse

title: biden manchin democrats build back better agenda us politics live
story: The blog will have more coming up, so stay tuned.“The president has every intention of running for reelection,” the White House press secretary said in response. Biden’s sinking approval ratings have intensified questions over whether he will seek a second term, although the president and his team insist he intends to do so.Psaki said the president looked forward to “communicating directly” with Manchin about the Build Back Better Act, adding that the senator has been acting “in good faith” throughout the negotiations. The press secretary said the meeting represented a “continuation of that conversation,” but she would not outline what sticking points remain for Manchin before he will support the bill.“On Wednesday, December 15, the President will travel to Ft. Campbell, Kentucky for a storm briefing, and to Mayfield and Dawson Springs, Kentucky to survey storm damage following the devastating tornadoes and extreme weather,” the White House said in a new advisory. The president confirmed his travel plans after meeting with several senior advisers to discuss the federal government’s response to the storms, which killed at least 64 people in Kentucky. “We’re going to get this done. We’re going to be there as long as it takes to help,” Biden said in the Oval Office moments ago. The president also promised to provide states with “whatever they need when they need it” to help residents affected by the storms.  Biden has already approved a major disaster declaration in Kentucky, making federal funds available to help residents find temporary housing and start home repairs. Assuming the House also approves the contempt resolution, which seems highly likely, the justice department will need to determine whether to prosecute Meadows. The justice department is already prosecuting Steve Bannon for refusing to cooperate with the select committee. A federal grand jury indicted the former Trump adviser last month on two counts of contempt of Congress. The meeting comes after Meadows ended his cooperation with the committee, claiming investigators were not respecting the former president’s claims of executive privilege over certain records. However, the Democratic chair of the committee, Bennie Thompson, said in a letter to Meadows’ attorney last week that his client is also refusing to discuss his own personal records, which are not subject to executive privilege claims.  “There is no legitimate legal basis for Mr. Meadows to refuse to cooperate with the Select Committee and answer questions about the documents he produced, the personal devices and accounts he used, the events he wrote about in his newly released book, and, among other things, his other public statements,” Thompson said in his letter.  “The Select Committee is left with no choice but to advance contempt proceedings and recommend that the body in which Mr. Meadows once served refer him for criminal prosecution.”Speaking to reporters on Capitol Hill, Manchin said he is concerned about some of the bill’s programs expiring after a year or a few years while the costs of the legislation extend over 10 years. However, if Democrats attempt to alter the bill to better reflect Manchin’s concerns, that time-consuming process will likely stretch well into 2022. And Democratic leaders are still hoping they can pass the bill before the end of the year, in order to allow checks from the expanded child tax credit program to be mailed out next month.Powerful tornadoes barrelled through five US states on Friday, levelling houses and factories and bringing down power lines. In Kentucky, the worst-hit state, one tornado alone followed an extraordinarily long and destructive path of more than 200 miles. Authorities are still tallying the devastation, and the death toll has not been confirmed, but Kentucky’s governor, Andy Beshear, estimated on Monday that at least 64 people had died there with dozens more unaccounted for. At least six people have been killed in Illinois, four in Tennessee, two in Arkansas and two in Missouri. One of the hardest hit towns was Mayfield in west Kentucky, where a candle factory was levelled, killing at least eight people.  Police and fire stations in Mayfield were destroyed, homes were flattened or lost roofs, giant trees were uprooted and street signs mangled.  “Thank you @POTUS for your rapid approval of Kentucky’s Major Disaster Declaration,” the Republican leader said on Twitter. “Our entire congressional delegation came together to support @GovAndyBeshear’s request. I appreciate the Administration’s quick work to speed resources to help deal with this crisis.” Biden approved the request last night, allowing Kentucky to access federal resources to help provide residents affected by the tornadoes with temporary housing and money for home repairs, among other services. “With this amount of damage and rubble, it may be a week or even more before we have a final count on the number of lost lives,” Beshear said. Officials believe there are currently at least 105 state residents who are unaccounted for, and search teams are working to find them. “I know, like the folks in western Kentucky, I’m not doing so well today, and I’m not sure how many of us are,” Beshear said. The governor said he was taking notes on the confirmed deaths this morning, and he realized that he was writing on the back of one of his children’s school assignments. The assignment was about inertia, the scientific principle that objects in motion will stay in motion. “So we’re going to keep putting one foot in front of the other and push through this,” Beshear said. “To the people of western Kentucky, we’re not going anywhere. We’re going to be with you today. We’re going to be with you tomorrow. And we’re going to be there with you to rebuild.” Speaking at a press conference this morning, the Democratic governor noted that 18 of the known victims are still unidentified. “Of the ones that we know, the age – the age range is five months to 86 years, and six are younger than 18,” Beshear said, his voice breaking with emotion as he updated the death toll. The governor had previously said that officials feared the death toll would exceed 100, but those estimations have decreased as more potential victims have been found alive.The president will be briefed by Secretary of Homeland Security Alejandro Mayorkas, Fema administrator Deanne Criswell and Homeland security adviser Liz Sherwood-Randall in about 45 minutes. Biden has already declared a federal emergency in Kentucky, as rescue efforts continue across the state. The Democratic governor of Kentucky, Andy Beshear, had initially said officials feared the death toll would exceed 100, but that number is now expected to be closer to 50. “We are praying that maybe original estimates of those we have lost were wrong. If so, it’s going to be pretty wonderful,” the governor said yesterday. Read more of the ’s coverage on the tornadoes: Fauci warned that the Omicron variant appeared to be able to “evade” the protection of two initial doses of the mRNA-type Covid vaccines – PfizerBioNTech’s and Moderna’s – as well as post-infection therapies such as monoclonal antibodies and convalescent plasma. Omicron is spurring new fears as US infections begin to surge again, with infections currently still led by the highly-transmissable Delta variant that has dominated since the summer. Fauci said an extra vaccine shot provides “optimal” protection against Omicron, even though the government’s official designation of “fully vaccinated” remained at two doses of Pfizer or Moderna, or one of Johnson &amp Johnson’s vaccine, which was developed by another method. Democrats are trying to pass the legislation using a process known as reconciliation, meaning they only need 51 votes to get it approved rather than the 60 votes that are usually necessary when Republicans filibuster a bill. Over the summer, Manchin called for a “strategic pause” in the negotiations over the $1.75tn spending package until lawmakers had a clearer picture of how inflation was faring. However, since Manchin published that September op-ed, a number of economists and market analysts have said they do not believe the bill will significantly worsen inflation, which may have somewhat alleviated the West Virginia senator’s concerns. For more information on the latest inflation news, read the ’s report from Friday: Centrist Senator Joe Manchin will reportedly meet with Joe Biden in the next couple of days, as Democrats race to pass the president’s Build Back Better Act before the end of the year. If Democrats cannot pass their bill before the end of the year, it will jeopardize the extension of the expanded child tax credits, which have become a life-saving benefit for many American families over the past year. If the bill does not pass, the party will likely have a much harder time convincing voters to reelect them next year, and Biden could face the same dilemma in 2024. So the stakes could not be higher, and once again, all eyes are on Manchin to see whether he will allow Democrats to move forward. Stay tuned.

title: hse seeks to use up moderna supplies that are close to expiry date
story: About half of all boosters are now being administered in GP surgeries and pharmacies, with the rest given in mass vaccination centres. Photograph: iStockOne-third of people who received a Covid-19 booster dose last week were given the Moderna vaccine, as the Health Service Executive (HSE) seeks to use up supplies that are close to their expiry date.Under a change of policy, most people being offered booster shots at mass vaccination centres are now being given Moderna rather than Pfizer. Last week, Moderna accounted for 35 per cent of booster shots administered, while the rest were Pfizer, according to HSE figures. Up to then, the use of Moderna was negligible compared to Pfizer.The HSE has over 1 million doses of Moderna that are due to expire at different dates in the near future, a spokesman confirmed. The use of Moderna is confined to those aged 30 years and over under-30s will be administered Pfizer.As during the original vaccine rollout, people cannot choose which vaccine they receive.The HSE had been aiming to administer 240,000 booster doses last week, which would have been the highest figure so far in the booster rollout. However, Storm Barra forced the closure of some centres, so the number of doses administered was about 220,000.About half of all boosters are now being administered in GP surgeries and pharmacies, with the rest given in mass vaccination centres.Last week for example, 80,000 boosters were provided by GP practices and 30,000 by pharmacies, while 110,000 were administered at vaccination centres.On Sunday, 20,000 people received their booster dose at a walk-in centre, up from 15,000 the previous Sunday.It is planned to further increase the throughput in vaccination centres, from a maximum of 160,000 to 200,000 a week, while maintaining numbers passing through GP surgeries and pharmacies.In contrast to the original vaccine rollout earlier in the year, supply is not a constraint with adequate stocks of mRNA vaccines available to meet demand.This time around, however, the large centre that previously operated at the Aviva Stadium is not available as it is needed for sporting events. At present, the biggest vaccination centres in the capital are Citywest and Croke Park, both of which have 50 booths.The centre at UCD, which saw long queues at times last week, has only 10 booths, but this is being increased to 15. The Croke Park centre also has 10 booths, and a new centres at Richmond Barracks in Inchicore is due to open later this week.Centres are currently offering boosters to people aged 60-69, 50-59, healthcare workers, and younger people in vulnerable groups.So far, 157,000 people are 80 years and over have received a booster, as have 285,000 people aged 70-79. Over 271,000 60-69-year-olds have had a third dose, along with 190,000 50-59-year-olds.Not everyone in these age-groups is eligible yet to receive a booster, as at least five months has to elapse since completion of their primary vaccine course, or three months if they got the Janssen vaccine.The HSE is currently working on revised plans to speed up the booster programme for adults and teenagers, and to begin administering vaccines to children aged 5-11 years.It aims to have 1.5 million booster doses administered by Christmas. The National Public Health Emergency Team (Nphet) meets again on Thursday to consider what fresh advice to issue to Government.Everything you need to know about the Covid-19 outbreakStay on top of the latest news with our daily newsletters each morning, lunchtime and evening

title: facebook removes page of ex ucd professor over covid misinformation
story: Dolores Cahill ceased her employment as a UCD professor  at the start of this academic year amid increasing controversy about her public remarks on Covid-19 and vaccinations. Photograph: The Facebook has removed the page of Dolores Cahill, a former UCD Professor and prominent anti-vaccination activist.The page, which had more that 130,000 followers, was removed by the social media giant as part of its “aggressive steps to fight harmful Covid-19 misinformation on our platforms,” said a spokeswoman for Meta, Facebook’s parent company.Another page, which appears to be linked to Ms Cahill and has a much smaller following, is still active.Over the course of the pandemic Ms Cahill has become one of the most prominent purveyors of Covid-19 misinformation both in Ireland and internationally.The academic has a history of making outlandish claims relating to the pandemic which are not supported by evidence, including that facemasks lower the IQ of children.She ceased her employment as a UCD professor in the field of proteomics in UCD at the start of this academic year amid increasing controversy about her public remarks on Covid-19 and vaccinations. She had applied for retirement some months previously.The university had faced repeated calls to take action against the academic but said that the principle of academic independence prevented it from doing so.Last month she was fined £2,500 by a London court for holding an anti-lockdown protest in “flagrant breach” of Covid restrictions.Research from the Institute of Strategic Dialogue (ISD) in October found that a network founded by Ms Cahill on Facebook almost doubled in reach this year, despite pledges by Facebook to tackle pandemic-related misinformation.The network, known as the World Doctors Alliance (WDA), is made up of 12 academics and doctors, including three who have been struck off or suspended.At the start of the pandemic, its members were being followed by only 3,500 people on Facebook. By July 1st, 2021, that figure had grown to 460,179. The group was founded as an offshoot of another conspiracy theory group, the World Freedom Alliance, of which Ms Cahill is President.Facebook has faced sustained criticism for not taking enough action against Covid-19 misinformation on the platform, including from Frances Haugen, a former employee turned whistleblower, who recently released thousands of pages of damning documents detailing the company’s internal workings.On Monday, a Meta spokeswoman said that since the pandemic began it “has removed over 16 million pieces of content from Facebook and Instagram containing harmful Covid-19 misinformation and have taken down groups and pages for repeatedly sharing this material.“This includes Dolores Cahill’s Facebook Page. We’ve also added warning labels to more than 167 million pieces of additional Covid-19 content thanks to our network of fact-checking partners.”Ms Cahill has been asked for comment.Stay on top of the latest news with our daily newsletters each morning, lunchtime and evening

title: russia vetoes irish led un resolution on climate action
story: The resolution sought to take action to prevent conflict posed by climate change and to make the issue a permanent fixture on the council’s agenda. Photograph: iStockRussia has vetoed a United Nations security council resolution on climate and security brought forward by Ireland and Niger, which was co-sponsored by 113 member states.Minister for Foreign Affairs Simon Coveney said the decision of one country to use its veto to block the move “very disappointing”.The resolution sought to take action to prevent conflict posed by climate change and to make the issue a permanent fixture on the council’s agenda.Speaking to The , Mr Coveney said: “It’s a reminder of how outdated the veto system in the security council actually is. Because not only is that system outdated but I think the view that Russia holds on climate change as a driver of conflict is also outdated.“They are very much isolated, I think, in their view that these two issues shouldn’t be connected… To deny that that link and that connection is really head-in-the-sand stuff at this stage“It shows how the inappropriate use of a veto can be totally contrary to to what the mainstream opinion is internationally in terms of calls for action on a hugely important issue.”The resolution was drafted and negotiated by Ireland and Niger following the council meeting on climate and security chaired by Taoiseach Micheál Martin on September 23rd in New York during Ireland’s presidency of the council.“The impact of climate change is global and our collective security is at risk,” Mr Martin said.“The resolution sought to consolidate the climate and security agenda within the council’s programme of work. Its adoption would have been an important first step in establishing a strengthened framework for future action,” Mr Coveney explained on Monday.Co-sponsorsIreland and Niger, who jointly lead the Expert Group on Climate and Security, guided extensive consultations on the text for over the past two months, securing the support of 12 council members. In spite of strong support from more than 100 co-sponsoring countries, Russia – a permanent council member – voted against the resolution, along with one elected member, India.“Although this is disappointing, the process confirms that the majority of UN member states believe the council should factor the security risks of climate change into its decision-making,” Mr Coveney said.Ireland had committed to advancing the issue of climate and security during its time on the council, and this work represented a major step forward, he said.“It has highlighted the relevance of climate risks to international peace and security, and Ireland’s commitment to engaging constructively on such a key issue. We have consolidated support at the UN, and can galvanise work to focus on this issue in the future.”The question of the security implications of climate change would not go away, the Minister said. “Recent analysis could not be more clear – the adverse effects of climate change are only going to worsen, contributing to insecurity and exacerbating conflict. It is telling that 80 per cent of UN peacekeepers are deployed in countries that are the most exposed to climate change.”Ireland would continue to prioritise inclusion of climate “in relevant council products, and we will work to advance this agenda for the remainder of our time on the security council and beyond”, he added.The council has considered climate security since 2007 and acknowledged environmental challenges, such as droughts and degradation of agricultural land in fuelling conflict – notably in areas such as the Sahel and Horn of Africa. But it has not laid out a systemic approach in assessing risks and responding to them.A senior Pentagon official warned recently the US military was “not ready” to handle climate change, a national security issue that touched nearly every aspect of defence department planning.“We are not where we should be, and now is beyond the time when we need to get in front of that challenge,” deputy defence secretary Kathleen Hicks told CNN.Beyond rising sea levels and extreme weather, climate change has opened up new areas of strategic competition like the Arctic and intensified the competition for scarce resources, she noted, such as the raw materials required to make the lithium-ion batteries crucial to electric vehicles.Stay on top of the latest news with our daily newsletters each morning, lunchtime and evening

title: gchqs christmas card can outsmart 11 year old
story: Never mind Secret Santa or where the TV remote control has been hidden, the real mysteries this Christmas have been set  by GCHQ.The Cheltenham-based cyber spy agency has appealed to Britain’s young people to “discover their inner intelligence officer” by decoding a set of fiendish puzzles contained in their Christmas card.  The quiz, aimed at youngsters with an interest in science, technology, engineering and maths (STEM), has seven puzzles, increasing in difficulty.Rather worryingly, GCHQ has encouraged Britain’s adults to “test their skills as well and see if they are as clever as an 11-year-old”.  The agency hopes secondary schools and colleges up and down the country will take part in their Christmas challenge.They hope more young people will take an interest in STEM subjects and consider future careers in the intelligence services.Director GCHQ, Sir Jeremy Fleming, said: “From Enigma to artificial intelligence, GCHQ's history is full of talented people tackling the country’s most complex challenges. If we’re to help keep the country safe, problem-solving skills and teamwork are absolutely crucial.    “That’s why this year’s Christmas puzzles are aimed at young people.    “I want to show young people that thinking differently is a gift. It is only with the right mix of minds that they can solve seemingly impossible problems, just like we do at GCHQ.” The GCHQ Christmas card is traditionally sent to other spy agencies and partners across the world.This year the card sets a not-so-secret mission for young people through a set of puzzles which increase in difficulty, each aimed at a particular age group.To support greater take up of STEM subjects, particularly among young girls, GCHQ has partnered with the organisation Stemettes on several activities over recent years.  Supporting this year’s Christmas card challenge, CEO of Stemettes Dr Anne-Marie Imafidon, said: “No matter your age, STEM skills, critical thinking, and problem-solving are important skills to have.In my work across the Stemettes with partners like GCHQ, we want all kinds of people to have the chance to explore these skills, and for those that enjoy this type of challenge to get an opportunity to further themselves in these areas.  “GCHQ’s Christmas Challenge is a fun festive way to do this, and I’d encourage schools and those who work with children to explore this type of activity as another way to engage the next generation in some light-hearted STEM fun.”Solve the puzzles, which increase in difficulty. Link each answer to the glowing node on the tree (below) that best matches the question or answer. Once complete, discover the hidden message, reading from top to bottom. Clue here: reading initials spells this message's answer. Simple! Enter your four letter answers in the grid. 1. This is the word you want 2. Noise made by owl 3. US state with capital Des Moines 4. Adult male deer What completes the sequence: GRYFFINDOR, UFFLEPUF, VENCL, ??? Within the grid are a number of hidden mines. The numbers indicate how many mines are in the squares adjacent to each number. title: level four lockdown christmas history timeline covid restrictions
story: On Sunday, the UK Covid Alert level was increased to four, meaning the epidemic is in general circulation, transmission is high and direct Covid-19 pressure on healthcare services is widespread and substantial or rising.In a statement, the four UK chief medical officers and the NHS England national medical director said the emergence of Omicron adds additional and rapidly increasing risk to the public and healthcare services.But what does level four mean in practice? Last time the UK entered level four was on Feb 25, when we were de-escalating from the most severe level five.During that time, the restrictions in England were as follows: This time around, the restrictions are nowhere near as restrictive.Here, we take a look at the history of how and when restrictions were put in place, and if it could mean we are heading for another lockdown. On Monday, 23 Mar 2020, more than 27million people watched the Prime Minister address the nation to announce extraordinary measures to slow the spread of the coronavirus. It became the ninth most watched TV moment in the UK's history. Boris Johnson asked the public to stay at home and said that the police would have powers to issue fines to those who left home without a reasonable excuse.The address effectively put England into its first lockdown, and three days later the regulations were made legislation, which significantly restricted people’s free movement by prohibiting leaving home without a reasonable excuse and banning public gatherings. People were allowed to leave the house to exercise once a day, but only with members of their own households. Schools were closed to all children apart from those of key workers.All but essential high street businesses were closed and some shops were permitted to operate deliveries. Police were provided with powers to fine people, and the first review of the restrictions on Apr 16 saw the lockdown extended. At this stage, there were 6,650 confirmed Covid cases in the UK, and there had been 335 Covid deaths. By May 7, the regulations had been reviewed again, and three days later Mr Johnson began to plot Britain's route out of lockdown. By the time the Prime Minister announced the beginning of the end of the first lockdown, deaths had topped 30,000, and there were more than 200,000 Covid cases in the UK.Addressing the nation again on May 10, he set out England’s roadmap for the next phase of the lockdown.The work from home order was lifted as long as offices were Covid-secure, people were allowed to exercise an unlimited amount in a day and the previous ban on people sitting on a bench outside was lifted, as the Prime Minister encouraged people to take more and even unlimited amounts of outdoor exercise, saying it was fine from May 13 to sit in the sun in your local park, drive to other destinations and to play sports with members of your own household. The third formal review came on May 28, and this gave birth to the rule of six. On June 1, for the first time since Mar 23, people were allowed to meet people not in their households in groups of six providing they were outside or in gardens. The change of rhetoric removed the prohibition on being outside without a reasonable excuse and replaced it with a requirement to have a reasonable excuse to stay overnight somewhere other than your home.By the end of May, there were some 4,000 daily Covid cases being reported, and 1,452 daily Covid deaths. But the vaccine rollout was underway, with almost 25million people double-jabbed in the UK.In a statement made on the 10 June, the Prime Minister confirmed that from June 15 all retail businesses would be permitted to reopen and that people who live alone or in single parent households would be able to form a ‘support bubble’ with one other household. These changes, along with the managed return of some sporting events and the introduction of the requirement to wear face coverings on public transport from June 15, effectively bought England into the second stage of the Government's recovery strategy. Major changes to England’s lockdown were announced on June 23. This was the last time major changes were announced connected with a formal review point of the lockdown laws. The Prime Minister announced in a statement to the House of Commons that from the July 4: The Prime Minister said: Our principle is to trust the British public to use their common sense in the full knowledge of the risks, remembering that the more we open up, the more vigilant we will need to be. From now on, we will ask people to follow guidance on social contact, instead of legislation.Following the announcement, the Government published guidance on what people “can and can’t do after 4 July”. This implied that, barring amended restrictions to gatherings most restrictions would be revoked from July 4.It paved the way for a relatively restriction-free summer, as people made use of the Eat Out To Help Out scheme, which saw the Government picking up 50 percent of the bill when people ate at pubs and restaurant during August. But we were only just beginning, and in July we got a glimpse of what was to come when Leicester became the first city to be hit with a local lockdown.Leicester was the first city to be placed into local lockdown on July 1.More areas were placed in local lockdown during the summer and autumn and by October there was a complicated patchwork of local restrictions across England.On Sep 9, the rule of six was reintroduced as the Prime Minister announced the tightening of coronavirus restrictions for England. He said that over time, the rules have become quite complicated and confusing and that therefore the Government was simplifying and strengthening the rules – making them easier for you to understand and for the police to enforce.He announced that from Monday Sep 14, people would be prohibited from meeting socially in groups of more than six in any setting.But as cases soared from 3,577 on Sep 10 to 7,045 on Sep 23, Mr Johnson announced that the following day on Sep 24, all pubs, bars and restaurants must operate a table service only, except for takeaways and imposed a 10pm curfew. To simplify the local restrictions, a tiered system was announced on Oct 12, which would come into force two days later. He told the Commons: In recent months we have worked with local leaders to counter local spikes with targeted restrictions. This local approach has inevitably produced different sets of rules in different parts of the country, which are now complex to understand and to enforce. So just as we simplified our national rules with the rule of six, we will now simplify and standardise our local rules by introducing a three-tiered system of local Covid alert levels in England, set at medium, high and very high. On 31 October, the Prime Minister addressed a Number 10 press conference to announce that a new national lockdown would be imposed from Nov 5. Setting out the details on Nov 2, he said the rules during the second national lockdown resembled those imposed during the first. Some changes were made at the end of November in a last-ditch attempt to save Christmas. The Governments in the four nations of the UK set out plans to allow families and friends to meet more at Christmas than was previously allowed under the coronavirus restrictions. They stated that during the 23-27 December period, up to three households could form an exclusive Christmas bubble.Equivalent legislation was introduced in Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland. However, alongside the legal provision for people to meet up over the Christmas period had been a message from scientists and the Government that people should exercise caution. But On Dec 19, 2020, the Prime Minister, and the Government’s Chief Scientific Adviser and Chief Medical officer, announced in a Downing Street press conference that urgent changes needed to be made to coronavirus restrictions. This was in response to rapidly increasing cases of Covid-19, especially in London, the South East and East of England, and concerns about a new mutation - known then as the Kent variant.On Nov 25, when the easing was announced, daily cases were at 16,608. By Dec 20, that figure was 32,441A stricter tier of coronavirus restrictions, tier four, was announced on Dec 19 to apply across London and large parts of the South East of England and came into force at 7am on Dec 20. The tier four rules were broadly similar to those in place during the national lockdown in November. In tier 4 areas, people were required to stay at home unless they have a reasonable excuse to leave. All non-essential retail and hospitality businesses were close and people could only meet with one other person in certain public outdoor places. Christmas was cancelled for millions.In tier four areas, the rules were not be relaxed at all over the Christmas period. No indoor gatherings were allowed over the Christmas period  - with certain exceptions to this, including support bubbles. In tiers one to three, Christmas bubbles were allowed, but only for one day on Christmas Day.Mr Johnson said: As Prime Minister, it is my duty to take the difficult decisions, to do what is right to protect the people of this country. Given the early evidence we have on this new variant of the virus, and the potential risk it poses, it is with a heavy heart that I must tell you we cannot continue with Christmas as planned.By the beginning of January, the death toll from Covid had topped 75,000 people and there were more than 50,000 daily cases being reported, almost a 50 percent increase week-on-week. The Prime Minister addressed the nation to announce a third national lockdown for England.He said that hospitals are under more pressure from Covid than at any time since the start of the pandemic and it was clear that we need to do more, together, to bring the new variant of the virus under control while our vaccines are rolled out.51 The third national lockdown came into force on Jan 6 as the Covid alert level was raised to its most severe - five. People were required to stay home and were only permitted to leave with a reasonable excuse. Meeting one person outside for recreation was not permitted under these national rules. However, two people not in a support bubble were allowed to meet to exercise.There were limited exempted larger gatherings from this rule, but religious services and some small weddings were exempt.The third national lockdown also involved the closing of schools, something that was not a feature of the second lockdown. The UK shifted from level five down to level four in February 2021. Mr Johnson set out a four-step plan for easing lockdown restrictions in England, as part of the Government’s roadmap out of lockdown. At the end of these steps, the UK would be back to Covid alert level three.Although the alert levels are largely for guidance, we are now just one level away from the most severe, which has always resulted in a full national lockdown. The caveat this time around is the mass rollout of the vaccination programmes. The alert levels are:The indicators for moving from level three to level four, as happened on Sunday, include the case rate being more than 250 per 100,000 population. On Dec 6, it was 502. Another indication is whether the doubling time for new infections is less than seven days, which it is with the introduction of Omicron.In order for the chief medical officers to reverse the escalation and for us to return to level three, the case rate would need to be less than 125 per 100,000, the R-rate would need to drop under one, the number of daily cases would need to be fewer than 30,000 and there would need to be a four-week downward or stable trend.Conversely, if the UK Health Security Agency, in consultation with NHS senior leadership and chief medical officers, estimated that the NHS cannot cope with demand for the next 21 days, the UK could be plunged once again into level five. More from NewsCovid vaccine passports: Everything you need to knowRetired BBC director caught with more than 800 child abuse images says they appeared ‘by accident’Handwriting title: one six people dementia spent last christmas alone research
story: One in six people with dementia spent last Christmas alone, research shows, with thousands more only getting 15 minutes of human contact in the surrounding week.The polling by the Alzheimer’s Society reveals a sharp deterioration among dementia sufferers during the pandemic, with isolation and disruption to normal routines fuelling increased levels of confusion.Families said attempts to protect their most vulnerable relatives, in the face of constant changes in restrictions, have left them feeling guilty and anxious.Decisions last December to “cancel Christmas” for millions of families - with a ban on household mixing for those in the highest tiers, and freedoms relaxed for just one day in the rest of the country - meant many of the most vulnerable saw no one.Families said they were left struggling with feelings of guilt and anger about the “lost Christmas” for the most vulnerable.The survey of more than 1,000 families found 16 per cent of dementia sufferers spent Christmas Day alone. Among those who had visits from family and friends, around one-quarter were limited to doorsteps, or held through windows.Four in 10 dementia sufferers who saw no one on Christmas Day had a phone call of less than 15 minutes as their only human contact. Of those who did see someone during the week of Christmas, nearly one-third only had a 15 minute visit from either a neighbour, a family member or a paid carer.For almost half of sufferers, the only visit they got during the week was to drop off a Christmas meal or present.The research found that after more than 18 months of restrictions, 60 per cent of people with dementia were now less likely to recognise family members.Two-thirds of family carers said they were now feeling anxious about this Christmas, with a quarter now having to cope with increased caring responsibilities due to an increase in their loved ones’ dementia symptoms.Kate Lee, the chief executive officer of the Alzheimer’s Society said: “For many this festive season, the magic of Christmas will be marred by families having to cope with an unmanageable and irreversible decline in their loved ones. As the nation looks to go bigger and better this year to compensate for a Christmas in lockdown, people with dementia need us like never before.“With your generous donations, we can make sure no-one must face Christmas alone and without adequate support.”Marlene Aveyard, 70, from Guiseley, who is living with dementia, said: “Last Christmas was the first year I didn’t see my daughter, Jenine, on Christmas Day – and she is 45. Christmas Day itself was horrible. I had no special food and I didn’t open any presents, I didn’t feel in the Christmas spirit at all. I’ve never felt so lonely or isolated, I just sat and cried.“I normally pull myself up when I’m feeling down, but I couldn’t. I’m still getting over what we went through and it was several months before I saw my daughter face-to-face again.”She said the help she got from the Alzheimer’s Society was a “lifesaver,” keeping her “on an even keel” when she felt at her worst.The charity saw a significant spike in demand for its services during the “lockdown Christmas”, with calls to its helpline more than doubling that week, from 2,097 in 2019 to 5,153 in 2020 .The charity’s website saw an 88 per cent upsurge in searches on its website, with over 1,500 visits on Christmas Day. One of the most discussed topics on its online community was around how to respond to loved ones in care homes asking if they’re coming home for Christmas, the charity said.The latest figures estimate that there are now around 900,000 people living with dementia in the UK, despite so many people with the condition having died over the last 18 months, accounting for over one in four deaths from coronavirus.On Sunday, December 12, The 's editors and writers manned the phone lines for this year's Christmas Charity Appeal. The 2021 edition wanted to build on the generous £836,691.86 donated by you, our readers, during last year's appeal. Here are some photos of our staff in action receiving your donations:More from NewsCovid vaccine passports: Everything you need to knowRetired BBC director caught with more than 800 child abuse images says they appeared ‘by accident’Handwriting in exams is too ‘tiring’ for students, headmaster warnsOsteoporosis: Over-50s who break a bone are missing out on vital tests, leading charity warnsBooster jabs to become mandatory for Covid passes, says Sajid JavidTry again tomorrow, NHS tells people battling to book vaccine booster as website is overwhelmedMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: sack prof luckhurst want transfer students tell durham university
story: Durham University students are plotting to make mass requests for college transfers as they step up their campaign to have a principal ousted.Students are discussing further protests against Prof Tim Luckhurst as well as boycotts next term if they are not satisfied with the outcome of the university’s investigation.The university has become engulfed in a free speech row which began with a student walkout during a formal dinner in protest at the columnist Rod Liddle’s appearance as a guest speaker at South College.On Monday, at least nine university departments and 14 of Durham’s 17 college heads wrote to students to either condemn the decision to invite Liddle or express concerns at the distress caused to students as a result of his appearance.Earlier this week the South College principal who invited the columnist to speak was barred from public roles, with the university accused of “hanging him out to dry”.Prof Luckhurst came under fire for calling students “pathetic” after they walked out when Liddle rose to speak. He reportedly shouted: “At South College, we value freedom of speech” as several students left the dining hall and is “stepping back” from some duties while the university investigates.Niall Hignett, a first-year law student at South College who was involved in organising a demonstration against Prof Luckhurst last week, said: “We’re not giving up. Students no longer want to be here, so either Tim leaves or we do.”He said protests next term could involve “mass requests to transfer colleges, rent strikes, boycotting” as well as further demonstrations.“Once the university’s report is concluded, we'll have more concrete next steps,” he added. “This isn’t just about Tim resigning – the university needs a policy update to make sure this can’t happen again – but if he goes it will certainly subdue the anger.“Students aren’t giving up this fight because they are yet to feel safe again in South College. We won't rest until we feel safe in our homes. That involves Tim no longer being our principal and the university reviewing their policies to ensure these foul iniduals are not platformed by the university.”During his speech, Mr Liddle said he was disappointed not to see any sex workers that night – a reference to recent controversy over safety training provided by Durham University to student sex workers.He went on to say that the “science or pure facts” are that “a person with an X and a Y chromosome, that has a long, dangling penis, is scientifically a man, and that is pretty much, scientifically, the end of the story”.Following the event, Prof Luckhurst apologised for describing the students’ walkout as “pathetic”. But his apology was not enough to quell their anger, and hundreds gathered at South College last week to protest, wielding placards which included the slogans “Proud to be Pathetic” and “Luckhurst Out”.The university’s student union has urged him to resign, calling his position “untenable”.A Durham University spokesman said the university “upholds freedom of expression within the law”, adding: “We have a strong and clear policy statement and code of practice on freedom of expression and we practise this across all areas of university life.” The spokesman said it would be inappropriate to comment further while their investigation continues.More from NewsCovid vaccine passports: Everything you need to knowRetired BBC director caught with more than 800 child abuse images says they appeared ‘by accident’Handwriting in exams is too ‘tiring’ for students, headmaster warnsOsteoporosis: Over-50s who break a bone are missing out on vital tests, leading charity warnsBooster jabs to become mandatory for Covid passes, says Sajid JavidTry again tomorrow, NHS tells people battling to book vaccine booster as website is overwhelmedMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: sick no shows postcard booster frontline
story: I spent Sunday afternoon in a draughty tent in North London, inputting names into a clunky old computer. By 5pm, my throat was sore from repeating the same sentences scores of times. “Do you have a fever? Have you ever had an allergic reaction to a vaccine? Have you had Covid in the past month?” At the end of the day, I had ‘writer’s bump’ on my middle-right finger (not seen since my A level exams) from filling in all those forms.When I got home last night I switched on the TV. There was Boris at 8pm, with a statement. We need to battle the “tidal wave” of omicron cases, he said, to avoid the risk of a New Year lockdown.“Half a million jabs were delivered yesterday,” boomed the PM, before announcing the emergency Covid booster campaign to allow 18 million eligible adults to book their jab by the end of the month – four weeks earlier than planned. “Get boosted now,” was the rallying cry.Well, Boris, I’ve been part of your booster army since January – a job that can veer between cheerleader, counsellor and gatekeeper, all within the space of five minutes. Yesterday I was part of a team responsible for dispensing 220 vaccinations.The news today is dominated by people who can’t book their jabs, of crashing NHS websites, of four-hour-long queues and unavailable lateral flow tests. The enthusiasm is encouraging – if infuriating to those unable to book. Yet despite all this, there remains an (often vocal) minority, who aren’t turning up for their boosters – if they have had the first two vaccines in the first place. Of the 250 people expected at my clinic yesterday there were about 30 ‘no shows’: those with appointments who simply did not appear.No shows at the clinic are irritating on a number of levels. For starters, because of the way the vaccine is stored: we are using Pfizer in this clinic, and doses have to be calculated exactly. Uncertainty over the final number of patients means the clinical lead is unsure how many vials she needs to open. (A vial holds six doses). Desperate to get our ‘jabs into arms’, we were forced to hawk our precious wares: I was on Twitter at 4pm, asking ‘walk-ins’ to come forward – at first under-40s, then people in their late 30s. It seems ironic that we have to beg people to turn up for something that might save their lives.The odd no show could be down to keen people finding walk-in clinics earlier in the week. But most likely it’s because our patients simply couldn’t be bothered, and found better things to do. Of the 12 or 13 clinics I have covered this year, there have always been no shows. During the Euros, we had significantly quieter clinics – funny that. On the day of the final, the clinic was cancelled altogether.But no shows beg a bigger question than pharmaceutical expediency. In the end, it comes down to why? Why aren’t they turning up? What excuse do people have at all to be ‘hesitant’, or even ‘anti’ about something that will not only save their Christmases, but their holidays abroad, their jobs, the lives of their relatives – or potentially, their own?As soon as Boris announced the miracle vaccine rollout in early January, I stepped forward. I’m not historically a volunteery kind of person. But I loved this work immediately – not only because my virtue signal was flying the vaccine clinic became my social life during the lockdowns, a completely different experience from my stay-home job as a writer. And more importantly, it made me feel like something bigger than myself – part of the ‘war effort’.My first post was at the end of January. There was snow on the ground, and it was freezing. Icy wind screeched through the fully ventilated clinic, as we helped 70 and 80-somethings take off layers of clothing to receive their vaccines. People were grateful back then – often tearfully so – knowing that the treatment they were receiving would probably save their lives. We may have received the odd box of Quality Street, and a few thank you cards.We volunteers arrived with our own arms out and our sleeves rolled up – we could not wait to get our first doses. So keen were some that the clinic had to weed out those who seemed to be volunteering only for premature immunity. The managers soon identified those who had true commitment beyond selfish purposes.As the year warmed up, the cohort got younger. Their medical forms got more straightforward, but their attitudes more varied and sometimes difficult. Most were happy to be there. Some spoke no English, and we had to mime the questions (hand across brow to signify fever, etc).Other patients were fearful and suspicious, demanding the Pfizer jab and “not the blood-clot one” (AstraZeneca). There was no choice of vaccine at the clinic there never has been. Even when we explained that the chance of a blood clot with AstraZeneca was minuscule – that you were far more likely to get this serious illness with Covid itself – the odd person spat out their annoyance and left.Then there were the people who tried to queue-jump for themselves or their relatives – a more understandable position for sure. But our polite “not yets” had to become firm at times, to say the least. Such interactions were tricky, but at least these people showed up. To everyone else out there: I repeat, why? The mRNA technique used by Pfizer and Moderna is not gene therapy it’s a one-time set of instructions to our cells that the body then ‘forgets’. The cry that “Ninety per cent of infections are among the vaccinated,” shows a basic lack of understanding of statistics: yes, there are more infections simply because so many people are mercifully vaccinated – but the vast majority do not end up in hospital. “It’s just flu”. Well, try telling that to my hitherto sanguine hospital consultant brother who saw a previously perfectly healthy member of his team die in an agony that haunted him for weeks.I could go on – as I’m no doubt will the anti-vaxxers, with their responses. “It’s my decision,” they might insist. “It doesn’t affect others.” Oh, but it does, I’m afraid. In fact, the way things are, the people who aren’t getting vaccinated might send us back into a lockdown, and open the door to new variants, on and on, ad infinitum, as well as clogging up ICUs and perhaps infecting old or ill relatives.This vaccine volunteer has a message for those who say “no”. Do you not realise that we are on the brink of yet another national emergency? That despite plan B (and the whispered about C) we could be heading for overwhelmed ICU beds and a cancelled Christmas? Is there really any excuse to be ‘anti’ or even ‘hesitant’ any more?More from NewsCovid vaccine passports: Everything you need to knowRetired BBC director caught with more than 800 child abuse images says they appeared ‘by accident’Handwriting in exams is too ‘tiring’ for students, headmaster warnsOsteoporosis: Over-50s who break a bone are missing out on vital tests, leading charity warnsBooster jabs to become mandatory for Covid passes, says Sajid JavidTry again tomorrow, NHS tells people battling to book vaccine booster as website is overwhelmedMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: working home forms new societal division readers return working
story: From today, people across the country have once again been told to work from home if they can, as part of the Government’s new coronavirus Plan B which was announced by Boris Johnson last week at a Downing Street press conference, amid rising concern over the spread of the new omicron variant.  For swathes of workers, ditching a frosty commute for comfortable at-home working will feel like Christmas came early, but not everyone has the same experience. The latter is evidenced by the tales of the chaos at the Foreign Office over the summer, described by Boris Starling in his article, which demonstrated the dangers caused by remote working. Our readers took to the comments to argue their case for and against the return to remote working. One reader, who works in the private sector, argues that her team works harder and are more productive at home, whilst another suggests it only suits those more established in their careers and hinders new starters.What is your experience of working from home compared to being in the office? Read on to see what your fellow readers have to say and join the conversation in the comments section below. I’ve been working on a hybrid model of working from home and in-office hours for over a decade, and I can tell you that one outcome of the working from home routine is that I and my team work much longer hours when based at home. It’s not unusual to find us logged on from seven in the morning, and finishing at seven in the evening.Companies and teams that either haven’t got or don’t know how to use the technology correctly, and are managed by leaders who apply the same management and supervisory practices as if their whole team was office-based, does not work. The model for successfully operating remote teams is quite different.Those able to work from home are often the middle class, and those that can't are often the working class, which forms a new societal ision. A ision that enables some to shelter from Covid, while depriving others of that same shelter.The civil service doesn’t even have the decency to come out of hiding even when the risk has abated. I find it odd that the unions defend this inequity. Maybe this new inequality should be recognised with some being paid more and others less?We run a small company with 22 staff, 18 of whom are software builders, system builders, IT maintenance and training engineers. Last year we had 14 plus office staff, now we have four more, and we are expanding as IT and software are in such high demand. We moved to working from home and never switched back.Now, there is no stress, we carry on as before while competitors have to organise their staff again to see how many can and want to work from home. It is what our staff want. Most of the engineers are on the road most of the time anyway.Of course, the less intelligent and low paid without qualifications call them ‘shirkers’ because if they could work from home, that is what they would be doing.I run a small business, and I spend half of my day interfacing with the working from home mob and getting nothing done. Tasks which should take five minutes now take five days, and things that should take five days now take five weeks or far more. We can't plan anything. I was not in the least bit surprised by last month's GDP. Working from home doesn't work for the customer, B2B or otherwise.I have 25 years experience in the workplace, including 15 years of office-based work in Tier 1 Investment Banks and Big 4, and 10 years working hybrid and remote for start-ups. Without a doubt, the most effective work environments were remote and hybrid.Why? Because when you're not being bullied, harassed or stressed, you work longer hours. It also encourages better communication, you avoid expenses, and it helps the environment as there is less commuting.Meanwhile, remote working reduces person to person viral transmission, whilst also improving work-life balance as you are less burnt out. Therefore, I'm amazed to see working from home described as bad and associated with work-shy personality types. My team works a minimum of 60 hours a week and are forced to take holidays.I particularly agree with the comments about the risks of moving services to other countries if staff are absent from the office.I manage a large team, and we had a conversation on Thursday about working from home and for those who can’t for safety or technical issues, they should continue to come in. I think everyone would prefer not to have to work from home again, but we have to follow the request. I hope this will be reviewed in the new year.The point which I think is missing is that working from home is a privilege and based on trust. Where staff underperform, then managers need to manage that or they are not doing their jobs.Maybe the Foreign office or HMRC is in chaos whilst they’re working from home - they’re civil servants.In the real world of private industry, working from home means we work longer and harder - there’s no commute and very few breaks. My colleagues and I have not stopped in the last two years. Company profits have never looked stronger.Working from home fans are clearly well established in their careers. How can it possibly be beneficial to new starters? I work in the food industry and have never had the pleasure of working remotely. Did anyone care about the ‘health emergency’ my colleagues and I faced on a daily basis?So long as you were all lazing about at home, did you ever lend a thought to the two tier society you were colluding with? Get back to the office and stop your moaning.More from NewsHandwriting in exams is too ‘tiring’ for students, headmaster warnsOsteoporosis: Over-50s who break a bone are missing out on vital tests, leading charity warnsBooster jabs to become mandatory for Covid passes, says Sajid JavidTry again tomorrow, NHS tells people battling to book vaccine booster as website is overwhelmedDurham students plan mass college transfer requests in campaign for principal’s oustingToxic volcano gases force thousands into lockdown in SpainMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: keir starmer give tv address
story: Keir Starmer to give TV address to the nation at pm tonight on Covid Omicron iantLabours leader will be allowed to give a pre-recorded statement on BBC One in response to the Prime Ministers broadcast on Sunday nightKeir Starmer will issue a pre-recorded statement on the BBC Image: Tejas Sandhu SOPA Images REX ShutterstockByDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  Dec | comments Keir Starmer will address the nation tonight at pm in response to Boris Johnson ’s statement on Covid. The Labour leader will make a rare statement via a pre-recorded message on BBC One reacting to the Prime Minister and speaking directly to the British people. It comes after Mr Johnson made a rare “ministerial broadcast” instead of a press conference to ramp up England’s booster vaccines.The PM announced a target for all eligible adults to be able to get a booster jab by December  - forcing the NHS to give around a million doses a day. But the format of his announcement meant the press were not able to ask questions, including on the Mirroraposs revelations that he hosted a No quiz during lockdown. The BBC can be required to give airtime for ministerial broadcasts “in exceptional circumstances, such as a decision to go to war,” according to the Corporation’s guidelines. The rules add: “In such circumstances, it may also be necessary for the BBC to consider whether responses from other political parties are appropriate.  Sir Keir has previously spoken to the nation in reaction to a broadcast by Boris Johnson. Labour’s leader yesterday said it “looks as though” the Prime Minister broke lockdown law by hosting a virtual No Christmas quiz with two colleagues by his side on  December . But Sir Keir said he would support a Tuesday vote on Plan B measures - crushing a Tory rebellion. More than  Conservatives could refuse to back making Covid passports compulsory from Wednesday at nightclubs and other large venues in England. But Labour’s leader said he would back the measures. He told the BBC’s Andrew Marr Show: “I’m not supporting the government on Tuesday, I’m supporting the NHS and the public.  “Andyou look at the science in relation to Omicron, the new iant, there is a real concern that we could be in a situation where the number of cases is doubling in as short a period as two days. “Now, I understand people say, well that hasn’t led to higher hospitalisations and deaths yet, but the sheer volume of cases is very, very worrying, and that’s uppermost in my mind. “So I’m not supporting the prime minister on Tuesday, I’m supporting our NHS and I’m supporting the public in relation to this pandemic.” Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Labour PartyConservative PartyBoris JohnsonPoliticsCoronavirus" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get our daily coronavirus email newsletter with all the news you need to know direct to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. This may include adverts from us and rd parties based on our understanding. You can unsubscribe at any time. title: muppet tory christmas carol parties
story: A Muppet Tory Christmas Carol: the parties of Christmas past, present and futureA festive morality tale about considering the consequences of your actions, with a little help from Charles Dickens and Jim Henson Image: GettyopinionByFleet Street FoxColumnist:,  Dec Updated:,  Dec | commentsaposTwas the night before Christmas, and all through Westminster the muppets were aposavinapos it large. They partied at the Carlton Club on the night the pubs were closed. They partied in Downing Street while drawing up rules for a third lockdown. They partied at the Treasury, the Department for Education, the Department for Work and Pensions, Conservative HQ, and the Cabinet Office.Even on a Zoom quiz, designed to help them be socially-distanced, the muppets still found a way to party, drink, gather, and in general make the Zoom call a complete waste of time and tinsel.And upstairs in the Downing Street flat, the lady of the house reclined on a golden sofa upholstered with angel wings, sipping champagne at the downfall of her nemesis.  There was a rap at the door, and it opened to reveal a Downing Street policeman dressed, for the festive season, as Fozzie Bear. Whataposs goinapos on aposere, then  he asked.The partying stopped upon the instant. Downing Street staffers, politicians, civil servants, press officers, policy wonks and wives, who all knew full well that partying was not allowed, stopped mid-swig, glancing uncertainly at the mistletoe, the Tesco wine stash, and the many households with which they were not supposed to be socialising. They waited with baited breath for the punishment PC Fozzie would dish out. He gazed around at the tinsel, the Santa hats, the unwrapped presents. You call this a party  he said. This isnapost a party. The beer is warm, the consciences are cold, and I didnapost see anything, wocka wocka! And the Detective of Christmas Past turned, and walked back through the wall of sound created by some heavy beats from the Prime Ministeraposs flat upstairs. The parties continued until past midnight, and then the Journalist of Christmas Present appeared, clutching a copy of the Daily Mirror, and accompanied by Ant and Dec. Parties raged while people died! intoned the journalist. What did you see on the Zoom call, Prime Minister We were following the rules! said the rule-breakers. We do not recognise these accounts! said people who drank so much theyaposd blacked out and woken up in a tree. Iaposm very sorry anybody noticed it, mumbled the Prime Minister, about a fortnight later. And the sensible Cratchit family turned away from the government. Bob Cratchit worked from home, although he had not even the money to pay for another lump of coal. Mrs Cratchit tried not to worry about her children getting infected at school, because homeschooling was impossible. And poor Tiny Tim, who had underlying health conditions, said: God bless the vaccination, everyone! I wish I could have it, but Iaposm not allowed for reasons no-one can understand.Unlike the police, the Journalist of Christmas Present did not go away. They stayed in the corner, looking for evidence the police were not remotely interested in looking for themselves. As the Prime Minister walked from his study up to his flat, past packed offices filled with giggling drunks, through leaving doaposs, Secret Santas, end-of-year prizegiving and other festive japery, he muttered to himself: I have been assured that all the rules were followed.Upon entering his flat, he saw his we, and his two children, and about a dozen other people. Who are they  he asked his we. Theyaposre my support bubble, said his we. What, all of them  asked the PM. She replied: Itaposs not easy, being Queen.The Prime Minister lay down in his bed, and tried not to hear the drumaposnaposbass. Keir Starmer then appeared before him, the Lawyer of Christmas Future. Prime Minister, he said. I come from  weeksapos hence, to show you the consequences of your actions.And he showed the Prime Minister a Tory backbench rebellion he showed him letters of no confidence he showed him the politan Police finally unable to deny any longer the mounting evidence of the nationaposs eyes. He showed him the North Shropshire by-election and a double-digit swing to the Lib Dems.Read more The PM saw his party, which voted to force people to show identity papers before voting, rebelling against efforts to make them have a negative Covid test or vaccine to go to the pub. He saw the Tories become electoral kryptonite for a decade.He saw % of the public disobey his instructions. He saw millions refuse to get the vaccine purely because he was the one who had told them they should. He saw his own claims proven wrong, his lies delineated and amplied, and his legacy disappear in public scorn.And then he saw the Cratchit house. He saw a family weeping for a loved one, and Tiny Timaposs crutch propped up against the wall. But how is this possible  he demanded of Starmer. How could little Tim die, when we have a world-beating vaccine rollout, and itaposs so harmless to the young   Starmer pointed an accusing finger at the PM. Because it is not world-beating. Because you have not vaccinated children when other nations have. Because even a well-vaccinated population includes people who are immuno-compromised. And because you let the NHS run hot all summer with high rates of infection with the Delta iant, in the hope of a herd immunity which has exhausted the NHS, and gave us immunity against a iant that is no longer our top concern. Tiny Tim died of blood clots and a stroke, which are much more likelyyou get covid thanyou get the vaccine. His mother nursed him, and she now has Long Covid, and is unable to work. His father cannot earn enough alone to run his home, or feed his children, and is in despair as well as grief. There are millions of homes like these, filled with weeping and fury as people curse your name, not just at the parties they know you had last Christmas, but the lies you have told since. The Prime Minister fell to his knees. I am sorry I was found out, he wailed. Iaposm sorryyou think I need to apologise. What can I do, to reverse my slump in the polls  And from the street outside, many voices rose as one to say: Tell the truth. Report it to the police. Say it was wrong. Correct the moral harm you have done, and we may yet forgive the personal price we all paid. The Prime Minister thought about this. Bah, humbug! he shouted, and slammed the door on his only possible salvation. news politics new-covid-rules-lockdown-booster-"Boris Johnson details emergency booster plans for UKByRachel WearmouthSenior Political Correspondent:,  Dec Updated:,  Dec | commentsAll adults in England will be offered Covid boosters by New Yearaposs Eve as Boris Johnson announced a rapid acceleration of the jabs rollout to battle the Omicron tidal wave. Addressing the nation last night, the Prime Minister said the country was facing an emergency in our battle with the new iant - and two jabs will not be enough to protect people. He warned that Omicron could rip through an un-boosted population, overwhelming the NHS and leading to very many deaths. Covid restrictions are also being ramped up after scientists discovered the new Omicron iant is much more transmissible and spreading rapidly across the UK.It comes after Boris Johnson announced last week that England would move to the Governmentaposs Plan B measures. Epidemiologists fear the iant could cause , deaths by April and that the NHS could be overwhelmed as Omicron looks set to overtake Delta as the dominant iant within days. UK Health Security Agencyadviser Dr Susan Hopkins warned of a looming wave of infections - and said more measures may be needed. She said: Itaposs inevitable that weaposre going to see a big wave of infections. What we are not yet clear on, and which is what we are basically making sure people go out and get their vaccination for, is how much that will affect hospitals.  So, what do the latest Covid curbs mean for you  Hereaposs the latest. Working from home People in England are being urged to work from home where possible from today. This is aimed at reducing contacts. The furlough scheme has not ed, however, as no businesses are being shut down at this stage. The advice is to work from home aposwhere you canapos. Face masks New rules brought into force last Friday mean that anyone aged  or over must wear a face mask to enter a wide range of indoor venues. These include places such as cinemas, casinos and bowling alleys. The full list:community centres , youth centres, members clubs and social clubs libraries and public reading rooms shops public transport polling stations and premises used for the counting of votes places of worship crematoria and burial ground chapels visitor attractions and entertainment venuespublic areas in hotels and hostels indoor areas of sports stadiumsPubs, bars and nightclubs are exempt. There is also an exemption for singing, which applies to, for example, congregations and choirs. Technically, a person could avoid wearing a face mask by singing, but the Government has warned protestors attempting to abuse this rule will be stoped. Daily testing for Covid contacts  From tomorrow, double-jabbed people who come into contact with an infected person will be told to take daily lateral flow tests for seven days instead of isolating. The new advice applies to all cases of Covid, regardless of whether it is the Omicron iant or other strains. Unvaccinated adults must continue to self-isolate for  daysthey are a contact of someone with Covid.This means strict rules forcing people identied as close contacts of Omicron cases to isolate for  days are being scrapped. Care homes From Wednesday, there will be a new restriction on care home visits. Care home residents will be asked to pick three people to visit and one essential care worker. Covid passports From Wednesday, England could be facing the introduction of mandatory covid passes proving your vaccination status to enter some venues, including nightclubs.So a punter could have proof of double jabbed status or, under the new pass rules, a text message or email from the NHS showing a lateral flow result to get into a venue.Firms failing to check Covid passes properly may be fined £, and up to £, for repeat offences.But Boris Johnson is facing a major backlash to the plan as Tory backbenchers look set to vote against the plan. The PM may get the changes though parliament with Labour support but given he is under major pressure over the Christmas parties plan, the rules could be watered down.  So far, there are no limits on travel, household mixing and meeting groups of people. Downing Street has also rejected calls to put new restrictions on hospitality venues, so your Christmas party can still go ahead. What about a aposPlan Capos  Officially, there is no Plan C. The Prime Ministeraposs official spokesman said on Friday there were no plans to go beyond what weaposve set out already.But Omicron could change things, and Health Secretary Sajid Javid is under pressure to bring in more stringent measures before Christmas.Further measures could include hospitality check-ins, tougher isolation rules, face masks in all indoor venues and further vaccine passport rules.
