title: schools would very last thing
story: Schools would be very last thing to shutCovid explodes - and only after pubsDowning Street confirmed schools will only closeeverything  - including pubs and restaurants - shut down in a nightmare scenario. No insisted Plan B is the right approach Image: AFP via Getty ImagesByDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  Dec | commentsSchools will be the very last thing to shutnew Covid restrictions are needed in England, Downing Street said today. Boris Johnsonaposs spokesman insisted there were “no plans” to shut schools in England and Plan B measures are the “right balance”. But Nicola Sturgeon may announce more restrictions in Scotland tomorrow, and Whitehall officials have been reportedly been drawing up tighter curbs for England. Draft plans - unconfirmed - are said to include limiting pubs and restaurants to outdoor dining. And the PM today refused three times to rule out bringing in tighter restrictions before Christmas Day. That has sparked speculation about whether there will be further closures to battle the Omicron iant - despite Noaposs insistence that is not the plan.  Questioned by journalists, Mr Johnson’s official spokesman suggested pubs and restaurants would shut before schoolsneeded. Askedhospitality venues would close before schools, he replied: “I wouldn’t run through the list of exactly in what order we would bring things in. “But it’s certainly true to say that we would always seek to restrict access to face-to-face education very last.” The spokesman said students can be sent homethere’s an outbreak but we wouldn’t want to see it happening as a precaution or a matter of routine”. He added: Moving away from face to face schooling was always one of the last things we did, and only when it was an absolute public health emergency.” The spokesman said the government had “only restricted it [schooling] when there’s the direst public health emergency”, adding: “There’s certainly no plans to do that. We think we’ve got the right balance through Plan B and our big uptick in boosters.” It came as NHS England ed to its highest level of emergency preparedness, a level  national incident. Health Secretary Sajid Javid said the Omicron iant accounts for more than % of cases in London and is expected to become the dominant strain “within the next  hours”.He told MPs that due to a lag between sickness and death, hospitalisations and deaths with Omicron - currently  and  - are set to “dramatically increase in the days and weeks that lie ahead”. Mr Javid confirmed he will go ahead with plans to replace isolation for Covid contacts with daily lateral flow testing from tomorrow. Despite the government’s website running out of rapid testing packs, he insisted there were enough in the state’s supplies. He added people should “check the website the following day”they cannot order one today. Mr Javid added the NHS Covid pass was being rolled out to  to  year olds for purposes of international travel from today. As the crisis worsens ahead of Christmas, the Government is said to be drawing up a raft of more stringent potential measures. England’s health officials have been drawing up a so-called aposPlan Capos - and an even more draconian aposPlan D’ to tackle the tidal wave of omicron spreading across the country. They could bring back Covid pass checking-in the hospitality sector, require firms to only serve food and drinks outdoors, or even force pubs and restaurants to shut their doors entirely. In Scotland, the nation’s Health Secretary said stricter rules are inevitable due to the spread of the new iant north of the border. Mr Johnson was quizzed by broadcasters after warning that cases of omicron are doubling every two to three days. The PM gave a televised address to the nation on Sunday night, where he said two doses of a vaccine is simply not enough to prevent the spread of omicron - and the NHS could soon be overwhelmed. In a massive escalation of the jabs rollout, he committed to offer a booster to every adult in England by the end of the year - a month earlier than planned. But chief medical officer Chris Whitty only said they would be offered an appointment by then. No insisted the PM’s version was right. People will be able to have their Covid boosters on Christmas Day, No claimed. Keir Starmer will address the nation tonight at pm in response to the PMaposs statement on Covid. The Labour leader will make a rare statement via a pre-recorded message on BBC One speaking directly to the British people.  The NHS will have to postpone thousands of appointments to meet the target of giving every adult in England a Covid booster jab by the end of the year. Health Secretary Sajid Javid said people with cancer symptoms would unaffected by the ersion of NHS resources to the vaccine rollout - but non-urgent care would be impacted. Mr Javid also said he could not guarantee schools would not be forced to close again due to the virus. Askedthis was still a possibility, he told LBC: Well, I donapost want to see that or any of these kinds of measures. Iaposm just going to focus on everything  we need to be doing, especially the booster programme. The reintroduction of work from home guidance appears to have had an an immediate impact after reports of a sharp fall in road traffic and passenger numbers on buses and trains. Mr Johnson faces a mass Tory revolt tomorrow over plans to force Englandaposs nightclub and event punters to show Covid passes - with vaccination or a negative test - from am on Wednesday. news politics tory-mp-marcus-fysh-slammed-"Omicron: Tory MP compares vaccine passports to Nazi GermanyByDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  Dec Updated:,  Dec | commentsA Tory MP has been slammed after he appeared to compare the idea of Covid passes to Nazi Germany. Marcus Fysh is expected to be among more than  Tory rebels tomorrow when MPs vote on forcing many venues to ask punters for proof of a vaccine or negative test.In September Mr Fysh voted in favour of the Elections Bill, which will force voters to show ID at polling stations.But today he told BBC Radio  Live: “You are segregating society based on an unacceptable thing.“We are not a ‘papers please’ society. This is not Nazi Germany, okay ” Told there was a “long way” between a regime that systematically murdered millions and taking a test before going to a nightclub, he replied: “It’s the thin end of an authoritarian wedge and that’s why we will resist it.” Jewish Labour MP Margaret Hodge tweeted: “When will we ever learn “Letaposs hope  is the year when we stop making flippant comparisons to the Nazis.” Barrister Adam Wagner, an expert on Covid laws, said: “Itaposs certainly not Nazi Germany, where there was state-sponsored mass murder, ghettos, torture, death camps and the literal dehumanisation and genocide of entire ethnic and other groups. “Letaposs not inadvertently trivialise this important debate through ridiculous comparisons.”  Labour MP Alex Sobel added: “Utterly Shameful. “Maybe Marcus might want to rethink his votes on stripping people of their citizenship, banning the right to protest and requiring ID to vote stripping many of their democratic rights. “Finally only compare Nazis to actual Nazis.” Boris Johnson ’s ‘Plan B’ will bar those who are not double-jabbed - or prepared to take a Covid test and show the negative result - from certain venues in England from am on Wednesday.It will apply to anywhere open beyond am indoor venues with more than  people unseated outdoor venues with more than , people and any venue with more than , people.Originally unvaccinated people would have been banned. But Boris Johnson announced a compromise in which theyaposll be able to take a lateral flow test and show the result, either through the NHS app or through a text or email from the NHS testing service. But more than  Conservative MPs are said to be prepared to vote down Plan B measures, which also include retrospective approval for face mask laws in England that began on Friday. Mr Fysh told BBC Radio  Live: “We live in a free society in this country. “A ‘papers please’ society is an authoritarian state that we should all absolutely resist.” He became embroiled in a row with presenter Rachel Burden, who suggested people want the “freedom not to be infected”. He replied: “Look, we are very well vaccinated in this country. It’s been a great success. People have the freedom to do what they want with their own bodies and the freedom of association.  “Andyou want to undo those things, you’re not worthy of working for the BBC in my opinion.” Ms Burden replied “that’s quite a personal statement”, and she was simply “putting across the case that many of our listeners have” that they don’t want to go to a pubthey’ll be at risk. Mr Fysh replied: “Well don’t go. Don’t go then. You don’t tell other people what they should do with their bodies. Sorry, don’t do it.” Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Conservative PartyNHSPlan BBoris JohnsonPoliticsNazisCoronavirus" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get our daily coronavirus email newsletter with all the news you need to know direct to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: airport worker raided lost property
story: Airport worker raids lost property and steals luggage in revenge for being sackedArfan Ullah shared a keypad code he had kept after being dismissed from Manchester Airport, enabling the thieves to sneak in and loot passengers luggageArfan Ullah spearheaded the overnight robbery at Manchester Airport Image: Cavendish PressLtdByAlec WhitakerAmy Walker:,  Dec Updated:,  Dec | commentsA rookie airport worker enlisted up to  friends to help him plunder its lost property office in a raid after losing his job. Arfan Ullah, , shared a keypad code he had kept after being dismissed, enabling the thieves to sneak into the store and loot passengeraposs luggage which had been lost during transit, Birmingham Live reports. As part of the overnight robbery at Manchester Airport, the gang even posed as holidaymakers, to make it appear they were the legitimate owners of the suitcases and bags they were stealing. They booked a taxi to and from the airport to aid their getaways in plain sight, with the cab drivers unaware the luggage they were packing into the boot and back of their vehicles were stolen. In two raids, three hours apart, the gang used the same suitcases they had stolen earlier to load up more items from the store. They later met at a rendezvous point to split the goods. Staff at Excess Baggage Group Ltd - which had fired Ullah the previous month - only discovered the thefts when they clocked in for duty the next day. They played back CCTV to see a total of five men pilfering the unit. It is thought a total of  people were involved in pulling off the raid. Ullah, who had gambling issues, was arrested along with two other suspects, after one of the taxi drivers was traced by police. Officials at the lost property office based at Terminal One were unable to quanty the value of the items missing. It emerged members of the group had attended the unit two weeks before the overnight raid. At Minshull Street Crown Court, Ullah, now a university student of Chorlton-cum-Hardy, Manchester, and warehouse worker Nikash Sultan, , of Birmingham, admitted burglary and were freed with  month community orders. Both were ordered to pay £ each, in compensation towards the missing luggage. Ateeb Qaiser, , of Manchester, did not attend the hearing due to testing positive for Covid and will instead be sentenced on December  - he pleaded guilty to conspiracy to commit a burglary at an earlier hearing. The raid occurred on March , , just four weeks after Ullah was let go by the lost property company. Prosecutor Miss Helena Williams said: Mr Ullah was in his probationary period and his performance was not satisfactory. Excess Baggage Group company, at Manchester Airport, collects lost property at the terminals and any items not claimed are moved to longer term storage overnight. The entrance for the burglary was at the car park located in terminal one. The door is unmarked and assessed by using a keypad lock. It seems Mr Ullah was given the keypad access code on February  - the day before he was let go. On the night of the incident itself, the last member of staff left at .pm and the premises were locked and secured. But a staff member the following day noticed a number of items had been disturbed. CCTV footage was recovered during that evening which showed there were two entries, the first at .pm and the second at .am in the early hours of the following morning. It can be seen on the first entry that two males entered the room and obtained access by using the code. They then left with luggage items and ed to a taxi. At .am three males ed to the room with the same suitcases they had took the night before. The taxi was traced and the driver admitted to taking three males to the airport. Two males left the taxi but a third male remained inside the taxi. He thought nothing of it. From the CCTV footage, it would seem Ateeb Qaiser was present during both entries. The first time he entered the premises with both males, but the other two males were not these two other defendants. He then acts as the lookout on the second occasion but it is not clearhe is with these two other males. Sultan was at the airport with Qaiser - they are seen getting out of a taxi and using an ATM. Mr Ullah was not present on either occasion, but he played a role in planning the incident and provided the door codes. There were a huge number of items missing however, there are no accurate figures placed on the items taken by these defendants. Enquiries show one mobile phone was in regular contact with another phone and Mr Ullahaposs phone had regular contact with aposNickapos which was Mr Sultanaposs phone. Mr Qaiser and Mr Ullah sent seven tests and  calls. They were in frequent contact. There is evidence that they met up in Oldham the next day. Inquiries showed on February , they went to the unit which shows there was some degree of planning. Mr Ullah and Mr Qaiser did not answer any questions in the interview. Mr Sultan confirmed he was known as aposNickapos but largely did not answer any questions. We cannot place any figure on the items lost. In mitigation for Ullah, defence counsel Hunter Gray said: He is deeply ashamed of his actions. He was immature at the time and has issues with gambling and misusing alcohol. He has not tried to excuse his behaviour and has taken steps to address his behaviour. He is currently studying at university and has ambitions for the future. He has been interviewed for a job as a hotel receptionist and is hopeful of getting that job. He is at a low risk of reoffending. This will be the first and the last time he is before the court. For Sultan, David Morton said: He was only present on the second occasion of these two trips. He is now working in a Sainsburyaposs warehouse but he needs to find his future and establish a trust with his colleagues. Finances are extremely tight for him. Sentencing Judge Tina Landale said: This burglary was planned and was extensive and there were up to  people involved. Vehicles and taxis were used to get away. Ullah, you had a signicant and crucial role. You used your knowledge of working there, which was a gross breach of trust. You provided the key codes to the premises and a high value of goods were stolen and these were targeted. It has not been possible to know the value or the quantity, but a large number of items were taken. It was clear you had been involved in communication in planning with Qaiser in advance of the burglary. In addition to the compensation fee, Ullah was also ordered to complete  hours unpaid work. Sultan must undertake  hours unpaid work. news uk-news britains-biggest-family-radfords-share-"Radford Family enjoys ‘North Pole’ breakfast and advent calendarsByJon Macpherson:,  Dec Updated:,  Dec | commentsBritainaposs biggest family - The Radfords - enjoyed meeting Santa and his elfaposs during a day out to a Christmas trip to a farm.Mum Sue took some of her  children to Mrs Dowsons Farm Park in Blackburn and shared pictures of the fun trip on Sunday on the familyaposs Instagram account. The immersive adventure included storytelling, making gingerbread in Mrs Clausaposs kitchen, building a bear in the elf workshop and of course meeting Father Christmas, LancsLive reports.Posting pictures to the familyaposs , followers, the children were all smiles as Sue wrote: Such a lovely day today at Mrs Dowson farm the kids had fun decorating gingerbread biscuits and meeting Santa and his elves.  Fans from the UK and abroad shared their joy at The Radfords latest festive adventure and wished them a happy Christmas. One wrote: Lovely job everyone. Merry Christmas from Vancouver Island Canada. Another asked: Whereabouts is the place situated Sue it looks such fun for adults as well as the kids oh and just have to say how beautul the kids all are hope you all had the time of your les [sic] Merry Christmas to you all.  A third wrote: Lovely pictures of a lovely family, Happy Christmas to you all. Another person commented: It’s so lovely seeing there little faces.Last week, Sue organised a breakfast to welcome Santa’s elves to their huge -bedroom home in Morecambe, Lancashire. Pancakes, pastries and chocolate Santas were on the menu for a festive “ North Pole ’ themed breakfast as the family kicked off the festive season. In a video shared to the family’s popular YouTube channel, Sue says good morning to her viewers as well as wishing them a “happy first of December”. Sue and her husband Noel, , are parents to Chris, , Sophie, , Chloe, , Jack, , Daniel, , Luke, , Millie, , Katie, , James, , Ellie, , Aimee, , Josh, , Max, , Tillie, , Oscar, , Casper, nine, Hallie, six, Phoebe, five, Archie, four, Bonnie, three, and Heidie, one.  Their th child Alfie was stillborn. Sue and Noel have previously said they are proud of the fact that they keep their family going without relying on benefits. Instead, the stars of the Channel  series  Kids and Counting look after their whopping clan with the proceeds from their pie shop and YouTube channel. For previous Christmas celebrations, each Radford child has around £-£ spent on them, costing their parents over £, in gts.  To make sure there are no mix-ups on the day, Sue has bought each of them a personalised sack to keep them all in. Sue hand wraps each gt she buys and it has previously been reported she can wrap around  presents every  minutes. She and Noel get through around  rolls of wrapping paper each year to cater for their massive brood. title: christmas card spies features hidden
story: Christmas card for spies features hidden coded message - seeyou can crack itGCHQ have unveiled their  Christmas card which contains seven puzzles to test your brainpower – but can you find all the answers hidden in the festive card The card comes with seven puzzles aimed at testing  to -year-olds Image: gchq.gov.uByZahna EklundAudience writer:,  Dec | commentsPuzzles are a great way to keep our brains active, and who better to set some fiendishly tricky tests than the intelligence and security organisation, GCHQ. The Government Communications Headquarters have officially unveiled their  Christmas card from their director, Sir Jeremy Fleming, and much like previous cards, there is another festive brainteaser to crack hidden within the card. However, this year there’s a twist – as the seven puzzles have been specially designed for  to -year-olds to try. Sir Jeremy’s cards are traditionally sent to National Security colleagues and partners across the world who work alongside GCHQ every day to counter organised crime gangs, terror groups and hostile states looking to do the UK harm. Get the news you want straight to your inbox.for a Mirror newsletter here.But you can download the festive card at the GCHQ website and take on the GCHQ Christmas Challenge yourself – and see how your brainpower ranks against your family members.Sir Jeremy said: “From Enigma to modern day encryption, GCHQaposs history is full of talented people tackling the country’s most complex challenges. If we’re to help keep the country safe, problem-solving skills and teamwork are absolutely crucial. “That’s why this year’s Christmas puzzles are aimed at young people. I am keen to encourage STEM skills, thinking dferently, and help foster the next generation of talent. “I want to show young people that thinking dferently is a gt, and it is only with a mix of minds that they can solve seemingly impossible problems, just like we do at GCHQ.” To support greater take up of STEMsubjects, particularly among young girls, GCHQ has partnered with the organisation Stemettes on several activities over the last few years. And CEO of Stemettes, Dr Anne-Marie Imafidon, is eager to see young girls try and tackle GCHQ’s Christmas Challenge. She said: “No matter your age, STEM skills, critical thinking, and problem-solving are important skills to have. In my work across the Stemettes with partners like GCHQ, we want all kinds of people to have the chance to explore these skills, and for those that enjoy this type of challenge to get an opportunity to further themselves in these areas. “GCHQ’s Christmas Challenge is a fun festive way to do this, and I’d encourage schools and those who work with children to explore this type of activity as another way to engage the next generation in some light-hearted STEM fun.”You can download the GCHQ Christmas Challenge on the GCHQ website, and the solutions will be posted on their Twitter and Instagram channels. Have you got a story to share  We want to hear all about it. title: citizen anne sacoolas appear uk
story: US citizen Anne Sacoolas to appear in UK court accused of killing Harry DunnAnne Sacoolas, , is accused of causing teenager Harry Dunns death by dangerous driving in a road crash outside US military base RAF Croughton in Northamptonshire on August , Teenager Harry Dunn died in a road crash outside US military base RAF Croughton in  Image: PAByJosh PayneLucy SkouldingFreelance writer:,  Dec US citizen Anne Sacoolas is due to face criminal proceedings in the UK charged with causing Harry Dunnaposs death by dangerous driving. The -year-old is accused of killing the teenager in a road crash outside US military base RAF Croughton in Northamptonshire on August , . The Sacoolas case will be heard at Westminster Magistratesapos Court on January , the Crown Prosecution Service said. It is understood she will appear via video-link. She had diplomatic immunity asserted on her behalf by the US government following the collision, and was able to leave the UK  days after the incident.  The CPS reached the decision to charge Anne Sacoolas with causing Mr Dunnaposs death by dangerous driving in December . Mr Dunnaposs mother, Charlotte Charles, told the PA news agency her family were feeling very emotional after hearing the news. She said: My family and I are feeling very emotional and overwhelmed, having just learned the news that Mrs Sacoolas is now to face our justice system. It is all that we asked for following Harryaposs death. A Crown Prosecution Service spokesman said: While the challenges and complexity of this case are well known, we remain committed to securing justice in this matter.The case will be heard at Westminster Magistratesapos Court on  January.Anne Sacoolas has a right to a fair trial. It is extremely important there should be no reporting, commentary or sharing of information online which could in any way prejudice any proceedings.Follow MirrorFacebookTwitterMORE ON Court caseDangerous driving" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: covid booster should wait called
story: Covid booster: Should I wait to be called in – or can I go for a walk-in appointment There has been some confusion overpeople are eligible for their Covid booster. People who are can expect to be able to book their jab or visit a walk-in centre, but there have been problemsPeople queue outside Moseley Community Hub Vaccination Centre in Birmingham for their Covid  booster jab Image: Anita Maric   SWNSByBenjamin LynchSEO writer:,  Dec | commentsBoris Johnsonaposs recent announcement about booster jabs and coronavirus restrictions has led to big queues.The Prime Minister announced an accelerated booster jab plan on Sunday, but this has already run into trouble.GPs across the country are expected to jab  million people every day for the rest of December to try and tackle the Omicron strain. The NHS website crashed and people attempting to book their booster on Monday, December  were shown a holding page saying the site is aposcurrently experiencing technical dficultiesapos.Meanwhile, large lines of people have been seen outside vaccination centres. So should you queue up for your booster or wait to be called  Iaposm over , should I wait to be called for my Covid booster jab   You do not have to wait for your booster jab, you can book oneyou are eligible. There has been some confusion over who is eligible, such has been the abruptness and speed of the sudden rollout. Boosters are available in England for everyone that falls under the following criteria:aged  and over aged  and over with a health condition that puts you at high risk from COVID- a frontline health or social care workerOver s can book a booster online as long as the booster is two months after their second dose. This will be extended to people over  on Wednesday, December .Pat Cullen, general secretary and chief executive at the Royal College of Nursing, said: We are concerned about the scale and pace of this expansion, given these same nurses are already facing huge demands under existing unsustainable pressures in every part of the UK health and care system. Am I allowed to go to a walk-in centre for my booster jab   Appointments at walk-in centres depend on where you live and your age. Walk-in boosters are available for the following people:aged  years old or overaged  years old or over with a health condition that puts you at high risk from COVID- The NHS plans to roll out the following, but stresses that this is not yet available:a booster dose to everyone aged  to  years old a booster dose to people aged  years old and over with a severely weakened immune system a nd dose to all children aged  to  years old who are not already eligible The government said: If there are long queues or all slots have been booked, people are encouraged to be patient and keep trying, or book online. Omicron is a concern as it is believed to be more infectious than other iants and the vaccine may well be less effective against it. However, while this is not proven, early studies do indicate that a booster jab can stop up to % of people from getting any symptoms of the virus. title: covid cases more double number
story: Covid cases more than double number on same week last year as Omicron spreadsThe coronavirus wave that gripped the UK last Christmas saw far less cases than the current wave, with the country recording , new infections last week, compared with , infections over the same period in The Omicron Covid iant is sweeping across the UK, sparking new measures and accelerated vaccination efforts Image: AFP via Getty ImagesByMatthew DreschNews Reporter:,  Dec Updated:,  Dec | comments UK Covid cases are more than double what they were this time last year as the new Omicron iant spreads across the country.Last week, the UK recorded , new cases, compared with , infections over the same period in . The coronavirus wave which gripped the country last Christmas reached a peak on January , when , cases were recorded - the highest daily figure of the pandemic.It now looks like the current wave will result in a far higher peak amid warnings that Omicron cases could reach one million a day.The warning comes after a further , coronavirus cases were recorded on December  - the highest daily figure since January. It is almost triple the , infections logged on December  last year. However, deaths have so far remained mercully low in comparison to last Christmas.Some  Covid fatalities were recorded last week - far lower than the , fatalities declared during the same period in December . In a bid to bring the Omicron iant under control, Boris Johnson has implemented Plan B Covid measures and accelerated the UKaposs booster programme. Huge queues formed outside vaccination centres on Monday as Brits scramble to get their jabs as the new rollout got off to a chaotic start.  Just hours after Boris Johnson announced plans to jab almost one million people per day for the rest of December the NHS website crashed. An error message came up on the site on Sunday and Monday, stopping people from booking their jabs because of apostechnical dficultiesapos. Meanwhile, Brits were left unable to order lateral flow tests online as the gov.uk said none were available. Nursing leaders and a cancer charity have now expressed concerns about how the accelerated booster programme may impact on the NHS.  Get all the latest news sent to your inbox.for the free Mirror newsletter Steven McIntosh, executive director of advocacy and communications at Macmillan Cancer Support, said: The Government also must not fail to ensure NHS cancer services are prioritised and protected this winter to ensure that nobody faces long waits and disruption in vital cancer care. Pat Cullen, general secretary and chief executive at the Royal College of Nursing, also raised concerns. She said: We are concerned about the scale and pace of this expansion, given these same nurses are already facing huge demands under existing unsustainable pressures in every part of the UK health and care system. title: dad spends 20000 building secret
story: Dad spends £, building secret bunker bar in garden to watch footieDad-of-two Jody Wainwright and his family were completing their self-build home when he decided he wanted to build an underground barusing the leftover materials Image: WILLIAM LAILEY   CATERS NEWSByWilliam Lailey Graeme Murray:,  Dec Updated:,  Dec | comments A dad spent £, building a secret bunker bar in the garden to watch football.Jody Wainright says his family love the stylish underground bar just as much as he does - although his we isnapost such as a huge fan of the amount of time he spends in his pub watching football.The dad-of-two and his family were completing their self-build home when he decided he wanted to build an underground bar using the leftover materials.Jody says that he decided on an underground bar to save space in the garden and because itaposs something he hasnapost seen before.  He added: I thought a bunker bar would be something dferent to the typical bars people usually build in their gardens. Itaposs something outside the box and also has the wow factor because itaposs not something you see all the time. After originally joking with the builder I wanted an underground bar, one week later they started digging out the hole in the ground.  My favourite thing about the bar is that no one knows itaposs there. Itaposs got a shed above it so itaposs well disguised. The structure was completed in around six weeks and we spent around £k on the materials for the bunker. One of the biggest challenges of the build was keeping the water out and weatherproofing the top of the bunker.  The secret bunker bar also doubles up as a cinema room where Jody and his family also enjoy watching films as on one side of the room there is a widescreen television. There is also a screen that drops down from the ceiling which Jody uses for watching sports. The -year-old, from Wakefied, West Yorkshire said: The bar was a godsend during the many lockdowns. It was great to have a lovely space we could appreciate and enjoy as a family. My kids love the bar. Theyaposre always down there having parties with their friends or watching movies.  My we enjoys it too, although Iaposm not sure she enjoys how often I am down there watching football. When we have people over they are blown away by the bunker when they see it. Itaposs not every day you get to go into an underground bar. There bar consists of a booth seating area in the corner, a bar at one end of the room with draft lager and cider. Thereaposs also a couple of sofas and a table in the middle.  The dad has spent money creating a space where he can invite friends and neighbours round for a few beers while they watch all the top games. He has splashed out on the decor and it is now like a home from home where he can enjoy watching his favourite team. It also has the benefit of being secluded and sound does not travel because it is underground and causes no noise nuisance to non footie fans.  Itaposs quite glamorously decorated and I also have a few bits of sports memorabilia on display too. Itaposs great for us when we have friends around because you can have the music on louder because people canapost hear it as we are underground. So we canapost upset the neighbours which is always a plus. news uk-news hero-vet-saves-puppys-le-"Stratford-upon-Avon: Vet removes pebble from puppys throatByDanny ThompsonGraeme Murray:,  Dec Updated:,  Dec | commentsA hero vet has saved a puppyaposs le after the poor pooch choked on pebble in a garden. Footage shows the steady-handed expert save the three-month old Jetta, a German Shepherd, after she guzzled the stone while playing in her owner’s garden.The poochaposs owner noticed the pup was struggling to breathe and rushed her to the vets, Coventry Live reports. Staff at Avonvale Veterinary Centre, Stratford-upon-Avon, took an X-ray which showed the pebble was stuck in her windpipe. Vets made several attempts to remove the slippery rock unsuccessfully and clinical director Simon Davies dashed to help from an animal hospital in Warwick. The footage shows Mr Davies using a videoscope to locate the pebble before carefully removing it from the pupaposs airway. Vet Sarah Ives told CoventryLive: “Jetta arrived in a collapsed state and was gasping for breath.“We straight away provided oxygen therapy and tried to ascertain what was causing the obstruction. “As we couldnapost see anything obvious, we decided to intubateand examine her under general anaesthetic. “Jetta’s colour immediately improved and she was stable enough for us to take an X-ray. “We very quickly found the problem. There was a stone wedged in her bronchibut fortunately it had only blocked one side of her airways, so she was still able to pass some air. “It remained a serious situation, though, so we called our clinical director Simon Davies, who came over from our Warwick animal hospital to help deal with the case. “He arrived with a videoscope which he passed down Jetta’s throat to locate the stone and carefully retrieve it. “It was quite a dficult procedure, as the stone was very smooth and kept sliding away from the instrument he was using to try and secure it. “We all let out a cheer and breathed a sigh of relief when he did manage to grasp the stone and carefully pull it up and out of Jetta’s airway. “Jetta improved quickly. She was put on a course on antibiotics and was allowed back home to her grateful family that evening. “She’s one very lucky girl as it was the team’s quick thinking and actions which very much saved Jettaaposs le.” Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON HospitalsTherapyDogsTeamDogs" data-immediate"data-immediate"Calling all dog lovers!to TeamDogs for your weekly dose of dog news, pictures and stories.Invalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: how covid lateral flow tests
story: How to get Covid Lateral Flow Tests as government website runs out of kitsAs the demand on lateral flow tests surges, the government website has announced there are currently no more available. Heres how you can secure yourself home testing kits in light of the test shortagesNews of the shortage comes at the worst possible time Image: DAILY RECORDByHarry Thompson:,  Dec Updated:,  Dec | comments As the Omicron iant takes hold, Brits are flocking to vaccination centres and making sure they are tested regularly to ensure their Christmas plans run smoothly.However, today the NHS website ran out of lateral flow tests with people being urged to try again tomorrow or to head to their local pharmacy. The tests are now unavailable on official websites in the UK, leaving people having to either make do with what they have or scramble to find them in pharmacies and other distributors. Double vaccinated contacts of people who have tested positive for the Omicron iant are told to test every day for a week instead of isolate. The timing is made worse by Covid passes for many venues and events requiring unvaccinated people to use lateral flow tests as an alternative method for entry. How to get Lateral Flow tests For those scrambling to get hold of precious lateral flow tests, the best thing to do is to use the NHSaposs dedicated postcode checker, which will inform users of nearby centres both to collect home tests or to get tested.The service will provide information about the centreaposs opening times and whether it is a test site or a collection point. It also provides a status on whether it is open or not, an address and instructions on how to get there. The UK Health Security Agencysaid: Everyone who needs a lateral flow test can collect test kits - either at their local pharmacy, some community sites and some schools and colleges. Due to exceptionally high demand, ordering lateral flow tests on gov.uk has been temporarily suspended to fulfil existing orders.The UKHSAaposs message was somewhat confused by Prime Minister Boris Johnson half an hour before when he said there was a ready supply of lateral flow tests available.It also goes without saying that people should frequently check back on the government website for updates. Why has the government website run out lateral flow tests  The availability of tests appears to have been put on hold while the government catches up with fulfilling pre-existing orders after exceptionally high demand. Speaking to Sky News, a Whitehall spokesperson said: We have plenty of tests, people can continue to get them from pharmacies and other sites. We have seen a surge in demand and that is putting pressure on the delivery system rather than stock levels of home test kits. However, Angela Rayner, the Labour deputy leader said: The governmentaposs inability to procure properly and plan for civil contingencies is reckless. Boris Johnson has his priorities in the wrong place. title: how each age group can
story: How each age group can book Covid booster jabs and what the new plans areAs the threat of Omicron impacting peoples Christmases appears to reach new heights, the UK scrambles to administer as many Covid booster jabs as possible by the end of the year - heres how you can book your booster vaccineOver  million people have already had their booster jab Image: Getty ImagesByHarry Thompson:,  Dec Updated:,  Dec | comments The UK is once again in a race against Covid as the new Omicron iant sweeps across the country. The new strain isexpected to surpass Delta as the dominant iant within  hours in London. Scientists believe Omicron is more transmissible than previous iants, although no solid conclusions have been drawn yet as to whether or not it is more dangerous than its predecessor.At the time of writing  people in the UK have been admitted to hospital with it, with reports that a patient has died in the UK after testing positive with Omicron.As it stands, the huge rollout of Covid booster jabs remains the only meaningful tactic for tackling Omicron. Scotland and Wales are aiming to offer the booster to all people by the end of the year, while Northern Ireland is also ramping up efforts by now offering walk-ins to over s. What has changed in the Covid booster jab roll-out plan   The original plan laid out that all adults eligible for a booster would be offered one by the end of January, however, the goalposts have now been brought forward, with the aim to now have achieved this by the end of . Eligible adults include all over-s who had their second jab at least three months ago. A joint statement issued by the Chief Medical Officers of the four home nations said: “Transmission of Covid- is already high in the community, mainly still driven by Delta, but the emergence of Omicron adds additional and rapidly increasing risk to the public and healthcare services. Vaccine protection against symptomatic disease from Omicron is reduced… hospitalisations from Omicron are already occurring and these are likely to increase rapidly.” How many jabs a day will be needed for the government to meet the target  The government is now aiming to jab one million people per day, double the previous target of , per day and dwarfing the , per day before that. Saturdays tend to see the most people going for jabs, with , getting theirs on Saturday, December . Last week, the most boosters that had been picked up on a weekday was ,, meaning there is still a long way to gothe government is aiming to vaccinate over  million people in roughly as many days. How can you get your booster jab  There are a number of ways to get your booster, however, it may be impacted by your age. While everyone over  can head to a walk-in centre, not everyone is able to pre-book. Read on for the latest advice for each age group. Over-sOver-s are now able to head to walk-in centres to get their jabs. However, at the time of writing, this age group cannot book online via the NHS website.There is no guarantee that people heading to walk-in centres will be able to get a jab, but reports of those under  getting them are increasingly frequent. People who go to get a jab via walk-in centres, but are turned away, are being encouraged to keep trying. However, as of Wednesday, December , over-s will also be able to book a jab online. The rush of young people trying to get jabbed before heading home for Christmas has prompted y queues and issues with booking sites for those eligible. In a Tweet, the NHS said: The Covid vaccine booking service is currently facing extremely high demand so is operating a queuing system. For users aged -, please be aware that booking opens on Wednesday  Dec. For all others experiencing waits, we would advise trying again later today or tomorrow. Over-s Over-s are now the latest age group able to book their jabs online via the NHS website. The age group was included as part of the Monday, December th rule change. They too can go to walk-in centres, although people eligible to book must have had their second jab only two months beforehand. Over-s All eligible over-s are now being encouraged to get their booster jabs, either by booking or by heading to a walk-in centre. Over-s Over-s are also being encouraged to get their boosters as long as they got their second jab at least two months prior. Key workers Key workers, including front-line health or care home workers, are eligible to get their booster by either booking or walking in regardless of their age.Vulnerable people, those who are the main carer for someone  or who live with people more at risk from the disease - like people with HIV or who have had a transplant - are also eligible to get their booster jabs. news uk-news kate-middleton-makes-flirty-gesture-"Kate Middleton and William arrive for the Earthshot Prize ceremonyByJenner NewtonRoyal Features Writer:,  Dec | comments The Duchess of Cambridge makes quite a flirtatious gesture towards Prince William in their Christmas card photo, a body language expert has said.The couple has released the gorgeous image that features on their  card and shows them relaxing on holiday in Jordan earlier this year alongside their young children Prince George, Princess Charlotte and Prince Louis.The shot, which has a sun-kissed backdrop, sees a beaming Kate and William place a tender hand on each otheraposs knees while George and Charlotte sit on either side of their parents. Louis sits cross-legged in front of his mum. And according to body language expert Darren Stanton, Kate placing her hand on her husbandaposs knee is a signicant part of the photo. He tells Coffee Friend : It’s quite a flirtatious gesture for any photo - especially one that depicts a r oyal family and the future of the monarchy.If anything, it reinforces the love the couple have for one another and William shows his approval by placing his hand on Kate’s leg. Such a personal move, almost restricted for romantic partners, again displays just how in sync the pair are as they match and mirror each other perfectly.Love the royals for the Mirroraposs daily newsletter to get all the latest news on the Queen, Charles, Kate, Wills, Meghan, Harry and the rest of The Firm. Click here to sign up.Meanwhile, Darren also notes that the image shows the family were genuinely enjoying a very happy time on their travels and that Princess Charlotte may have a dferent personality from her siblings.He adds: The first thing that strikes me about the photo is that everybody pictured is flashing a genuine smile - so often in photographs, no matter how important the person being photographed is, fake smiles are shown and faces can seem very disingenuous.  In this particular picture, everyone is displaying genuine emotion, which would suggest it’s a very happy time for the family right now. Kate always flashes a great smile, her whole face is engaged and her crow’s feet - the three lines at the side of the eyes - are visible, which denotes a genuine smile and it is congruent with how open and inviting the rest of her body language is.  Her maternal intuition beams through, as she has her hand on the back of Prince George in a reassuring way. While the two princes, George and Louis, have adopted the same pose and position with their arms and legs - mirroring each other, Princess Charlotte sits with a slightly more turned posture suggesting she has a dferent personality to her siblings. And Darren says the choice of this snap could give an insight into how William and Kate see their place in the monarchy - especially as last yearaposs card was so dferent. He explains: Kate and Will’s choice in photo could be anyone’s holiday family snap. It signies that the royal couple are going to be very much their own people. While they still make sure to be respectful of royal protocols in place, they show a keenness to bring the monarchy into the st Century and establish a more personal connection with the public and the public with them. news uk-news knackered-postman-who-left-woman-"Postman refuses to help elderly woman after fall at her doorstepByJackie GrantAlice Peacock:,  Dec Updated:,  Dec | comments A postman who told an elderly woman lying on her doorstep after she slipped on ice that he was too “knackered” to help has been sacked by Royal Mail.Postie Thomas McCafferty ignored the pleas for help from Patricia Stewart, , as she lay on the steps of her home in Falkirk, Scotland, last February in freezing conditions, in one of the coldest winters for  years.A Royal Mail spokesperson this morning confirmed that McCafferty had left the company, Daily Record reports.“We have been in touch with the customer concerned to express our apologies again and to update them following the conclusion of the investigation,” he continued.  “We have also now completed our internal investigation but we are unable to comment further on any outcome for confidentiality reasons.”Patriciashouted for helpfor around  minutes after slipping on ice and hitting her head outside her home.When the distraught gran-of-two, from Bainsford saw the postman she thought her ordeal was over. Footage of the shocking incident captured by Patricia’s neighbour’s doorbell camera and shared online showed McCafferty standing over Patricia as she let out a moan, before saying something to the postie.  But in response, McCafferty said “I canapost help you pal” and proceeded to explain that he was apostoo knackeredapos to assist the pensioner after her fall. He then left the stricken OAP without even calling for help. Thankfully, -year-old Hermes driver Karolina Domska found Mrs Stewart crying in the snow  minutes after the fall and helped her back into her house.  Mrs Stewartaposs family fear she could have died in the freezing conditions, with the pensioner - who walks with a Zimmer frame - suffering from bone disease osteoporosis. Niece Sheryl Harkins said: What this gentleman did is disgusting. He deserves everything he is going to get. He shouldnapost be working with the public. Grandmother-of-two Patricia, who lives alone, said she felt dizzy and fell from the top step, banging her head.  With the postman ignoring her pleas for help, she said she feared she might have been lying there for hours.At the timePatricia told The Sun: Twenty minutes I was shouting aposhelpapos and I was crying.I was lying partly in the snow and I banged my head. She added: Evenhe was knackered, at the end of the day thataposs his job. The gran said she was left with a lump the size of an egg on her head following the incident. Ms Harkins previously said she was still awaiting an apology from the postman.An investigation was launched by the Royal Mail and McCafferty was initiallysuspended , while an area manager later visited Ms Stewart to apologise in person and bring her chocolates. At the time, the company said it expects the highest standards of behaviour from employees. We regularly remind our postmen and postwomen of the important role they play in their local communities,” a company spokesperson added. We have been in touch with the customer concerned to apologise and to inform them we are investigating this incident.” “We are sorry for the distress this incident has caused.” Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Royal Mail Ltd.SnowPensioner" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. news uk-news man-scoffs--greggs-festive-"Sunderland man eats  Greggs festive bakes in under an hourByJade CulverGraeme Murray:,  Dec  A man has eaten  Greggs festive bakes in under an hour - a haul which contained an enormous , calories.Kyle Gibson, a professional eater, managed to plough through the puff pastry filled with meat, stuffing and cranberry sauce in just  minutes and  seconds. The -year-old from Sunderland, Tyne and Wear, put himself to the test of eating the most festive bakes in one sitting. The ,-calorie meal was tough going on Kyle soon after heaposd demolished his tenth pastry, but he journeyed on even treating himself to six mince pies as a dessert. The whopping .kg haul cost a total of £, leaving Kyle stuffed.  He said: The festive bakes only come out once a year, so I thought Iaposd give it a try. Theyaposre actually really good, but after the tenth one it just all started to go downhill from there. They were just so dry and flaky, and it got monotonous just eating the same thing over and over again. After eating them, I never wanted to eat one again.  Kyle relishes eating challenges and uses eating as an an endurance test which he can prove he has won. He plans future eating tests and is looking forward to more seasonal food as Christmas approaches. His next target is mince pies which he plans to film on video and before heading to the gym once he has completed the task. Since scoffing  festive bakes, Kyle hopes to do more Greggs challenges in the future like trying to see how many sausage rolls he can eat in one sitting.He said: Iaposve been doing challenges like this for the past five years. So once I do them, I go into a food coma for a little while but burn it all off at the gym and by eating low calorie meals on normal days. Iaposm looking forward to Christmas, and Iaposm even planning on doing another festive video of eating about  mince pies in  minutes. title: mum disappointed state 4 bacon
story: Mum disappointed with state of £ bacon roll from Starbucks with hardly any meatAmy Hope Preston ordered the £ sandwich and a toffee nut latte from a Starbucks Drive-thru in Newark but was very confused with what she saw when she opened up her rollAmy Hope Preston was shocked by the bacon rollByEllie Danemann:,  Dec | commentsA mum said she was aposshockedapos when she opened up a bacon roll from Starbucks to find just one aposfattyapos rasher.Amy Hope Preston, from Newark, ordered the £ sandwich and a toffee nut latte from a Starbucks Drive-thru in Newark on Friday, December , but was very confused with what she say when she opened up her roll. The -year-old medicine counter assistant told NottinghamshireLive : I was so shocked.I expected so much more for £. There was literally one slice of bacon in it which was majority fat and no butter. Ms Preston had quickly popped into the drive-thru after dropping her daughter at nursery.  She added: I got home and opened it up so I could put my sauce on. Thataposs when I realised. Iaposve ordered plenty at Starbucks but usually only a coffee. I definitely wonapost be ordering any food from them again. The mum put up a picture of her sarnie on a Facebook group which garnered nearly  likes and almost  comments. She added: I put it on social media because I just couldnapost believe it. Starbucks was approached for comment. Amy is not the only hungry diner to have felt disappoint by their food. In August one woman, who has chosen to remain anonymous, decided to treat herself to side of cheesy chips from the Sir Henry Segrave Wetherspoons in Southport, after a boozy night out. But, while the diner admits she wasnapost expecting gourmet food from the pub chain, she was left in hysterics when her cheesy chips arrived. It was only Wetherspoons so I wasnapost expecting a gourmet meal, but it did make me laugh, she said. Can you see the cheese  I struggled to. Bemused by the apparent lack of cheese on the cheesy chips, the woman decided to post a picture of her meal in a food review group on Facebook, and was met with mixed responses.Itaposs not World War II, is cheese still being rationed  one Facebook user jokingly questioned. Is that mayonnaise  another asked, while a third commented: I did think that was salad cream. A fourth questioned: Oh my gosh, thataposs meant to be cheese  Meanwhile, a slightly more rational commenter wrote: Apart from the lack of whatever is meant to be on top, am I the only one who thinks the chips look nice  Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON JD WetherspoonStarbucksWorld War " data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: neighbour coughed days flat block
story: Neighbour coughed for days in flat block before girl, , died in chemical incidentFatiha Sabrin was found unresponsive in her home in Shadwell, east London, yesterday afternoon before being rushed to hospital, reportedly alongside her mother and brotherA family friend has identied the youngster as Fatiha Sabrin who was found unresponsive in her home in Shadwell, east LondonByJosh BoltonAbigail OLearyNews Reporter:,  Dec Updated:,  Dec | commentsA resident in a block of flats where a girl died in a chemical incident suffered from coughing fits in the days before, it has been claimed. Fatiha Sabrin, , was found unresponsive in her home in Shadwell, east London, yesterday afternoon before being rushed to hospital, reportedly alongside her mother and brother. The childaposs death is being treated as unexplained and the Met said a special post-mortem examination will be scheduled in due course, reports MyLondon.Other residents of the building also reported feeling unwell and a full evacuation took place. Toni Santos Babi, a resident in the block, said: I and my flatmates smelled a strange smell in our flat, and I had a headache, and they had a cough and throat ache for the last two days.  He explained: Around pm firefighters came into my flat to measure levels of some chemicals and they found a higher number in the toilet. After the evacuation, the London Fire Brigade swept the building and discovered a quantity of chemicals believed to be used for pest control. Sabbir Ahmad, a family friend, said the Fatihaaposs father has been stuck in an airport since the tragedy happened as he was in Bangladesh on a business trip. Describing Fatiha, Sabbir said: She was a very bright girl. She was in my home eight or nine days ago and were discussing her future plans. She was very responsive and told me she wanted to be a doctor, and wanted to make something very good of her le. She was also a great writer, she received awards for her writing skills. Zara Rahman, headteacher of Buttercup Primary School, said Fatiha’s brother - thought to be aged seven - was back in school on Monday. But she is awaiting updates on the children’s mother who remains in hospital. Ms Rahman said Fatiha’s brother is “confused and in shock”. “He hasn’t seen either of his parents, his mum is still in hospital so we don’t know what happened,” she added. Asked when she first heard about the incident, she said “immediately”. “It was a shock, you don’t expect to hear that about a fit and healthy child. “Police said a chemical gas was found in the building. It didn’t make sense, it was like something out of a film, it’s just so unfortunate. You always expect all pupils toback to school on Monday safe.” A police car remains at the scene outside Nida House, which was evacuated following the incident. Most of the building’s windows are open and a cordon remains in place. One bouquet of flowers has been laid next to the block’s main door.Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Hospitalspolitan Police ServiceEmergency" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: prince andrew broadly smiles enjoys
story: Prince Andrew broadly smiles as he enjoys horse riding ahead of sexual assault hearingThe pictures of the grinning -year-old prince have appeared days after he was said to be "incredibly stressed"ahead of the hearing in his sexual assault case on January Prince Andrew is seen joking around Image: JIM BENNETTByRussell MyersRoyal editor:,  Dec Updated:,  Dec Prince Andrew is seen joking around as his lawyers are set on Monday to launch a last ditch attempt to have his sex abuse case thrown out. The Duke of York was spotted horse riding on the country estate near the Queen’s Windsor Castle home, chortling along with two palace stable workers. His new Hollywood hotshot lawyer Andrew Brettler is in place to meet the deadline set by a New York court by the end of the day, responding to allegations the Duke sexually abused a -year-old girl in . However, it is still expected that Andrew will be forced to face a civil trial in the United States against his accuser Virginia Giuffre, who claims she was forced to have sex with the royal on three occasions in . Ms Giuffre, who is now , was allegedly trafficked around the world by Andrew’s late paedophile pal Jeffrey Epstein, who took his own le in a jail cell last year as he awaited trial on a catalogue of sex crimes.  The Duke’s legal team have previously labelled her, as a money grabber who is suing the Queen’s son “to achieve another payday at his expense”. Ms Giuffre has accused the Duke of sexually abusing her at Epstein’s Manhattan mansion as well as his private Caribbean island Epstein, and at the London home of his lover Ghislaine Maxwell who is currently in a New York jail awaiting sex abuse and grooming charges. She is claiming damages for emotional harm and distress which could run into millions of poundssuccessful.  An onlooker who saw the Duke out riding on Monday said: “Considering he is facing a civil trial on very serious allegations, he looked like he didn’t have a care in the world. “He was laughing and joking with his riding companions and enjoying himself.” US judge Lewis Kaplan will on January  for the last time examine both submissions from the prosecution and is expected to call for a trial to begin next autumn. Sources close to the Duke have revealed he has recently been “staying up late” and “working on US time” to speak to his lawyers who are based in Calornia. The Duke’s case preparations have also been marred by infighting between his UK solicitor Gary Bloxsome and Mr Brettler, allegedly due to a “severe clash in personalities”. Mr Brettler is understood to have been “entirely unimpressed with the state of affairs” when he was hired at the eleventh hour in October after Andrew failed to dismiss the abuse claims against him, sources have disclosed. Meanwhile, it emerged on Sunday how Prince Andrew has had little or no discussion over his legal woes with senior royals, including the -year-old Queen who has agreed to pick up his vastly expensive legal bills. Until recently Andrew had “remained utterly convinced” he would still be able to join Her Majesty and the rest of the family for the public celebrations for the Queen’s Platinum Jubilee. But royal aides ruled will not appear at any public events or join them on the Buckingham Palace balcony for an RAF flypast. The prince has consistently denied Ms Giuffreaposs claims and, in , told BBC Twoaposs Newsnight programme: I can absolutely categorically tell you it never happened. A spokesperson for Prince Andrew did not comment.Follow MirrorFacebookTwitterMORE ON Prince Andrew, Duke of YorkRoyal Family" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get our daily royal round-up direct to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. news uk-news queens-unusual-christmas-present-archie-"Harry and Meghan reveal cute nicknames for each other as James Corden mocks themByJenner NewtonRoyal Features Writer:,  Dec | commentsThe Queen might have  young great-grandchildren - but it seems that at Christmas she is eager to get them all the perfect gt. And Prince Harry once revealed the Christmas present she bought his two-year-old son Archie last year - and it was just what he wanted. But the unusual gt, which the Queen ordered and had sent to the Sussexesapos home in LA after it was suggested by Meghan Markle, left TV host James Corden completely baffled when Harry revealed what it was during an interview for The Late Late Show earlier this year.As the duo took an open-top bus tour of the city, James asked Harry about fatherhood, his new le in America and quitting the royal family.  Speaking about the Queenaposs gt, he said: My grandmother asked us what Archie wanted for Christmas, and Meg said a waffle maker. So she sent us a waffle maker for Archie, so breakfast now Meg makes up a beautul organic mix, in the waffle maker, flip it, out it comes. He loves it. And now I have waffles for breakfast, bit of yoghurt, bit of jam on top. I donapost knowthataposs the right thing to do. Berries, bit of honey. Love the royals for the Mirroraposs daily newsletter to get all the latest news on the Queen, Charles, Kate, Wills, Meghan, Harry and the rest of The Firm. Click here to sign up. James interrupted him, saying: Sorry youaposre glossing over the fact that I cannot for the le of me imagine the Queen ordering a waffle maker to be sent to Santa Barbara. I canapost get my head around it. Harry replies: I donapost even know how to comment on that. Archie wakes up in the morning and literally just goes aposwaffle apos.This year, Harry and Meghan will be spending their first Christmas as a family of four after they welcomed daughter Lilibet in June.And as well as likely receiving gts from the Queen, one royal expert says Archie and Lilibet can also expect presents from their aunt and uncle Prince William and the Duchess of Cambridge.Archie and Lilibet are likely to spend the festive season in Calornia with their parents while William and Kate will be at Sandringham with their children George, Charlotte and Louis.In recent months, much has been made of the rt between brothers William and Harry and in an interview with Oprah Winfrey in March, Harry claimed William was trapped within the royal system - which is said to have left William furious.William and Kate are yet to meet their niece Lilibet in person.But when OK! magazine asked royal expert and author Katie NichollWilliam and Kate would be buying Christmas gts to send to America for Archie and Lilibet, she said: Yes, of course.They give gts to the whole family and that includes all of their nieces and nephews. This means also buying presents for Kateaposs sister Pippaaposs children - three-year-old Arthur and eight-month-old Grace. title: real life rapunzels hair long
story: Real-le Rapunzels hair is so long strangers refuse to believe her ageKatie Canha daughter, Dollie, had previously made headlines for her thick head of hair as a young baby - Now her thick head of hair has grown and many have seen similarities between her and Rapunzel, for their never-ending locksA toddler that was born with impressive locks is now being compared to Rapunzel as her hair grew rapidly and now reaches the bottom of her back. Image: CATERS NEWSByFlorence Freeman:,  Dec Updated:,  Dec | commentsThe speed at which babies grow a full head of hair ies signicantly - some fail to show any hair until they are a full-grown toddler whole others are both with voluminous locks. But two-year-old Dollie is being compared to Princess Rapunzel for the similarities in their luscious long locks. The little girl made headlines when she was born with an extraordinary thick head of hair, and two years later her locks are even more impressive - growing all the way to the bottom of her back. Her mum, Katie Canham, , says strangers now continuously compare her young tot to Rapunzel whenever they catch a glimpse of her locks. But Dollieaposs brothers and sisters - Archie, , Ellie, , Reggie,  and Sonnie,  - donapost share her impressive hair. Dollie, from Bromley in South London, got her first haircut when she was just three months old - and Katie now dedicates almost half an hour each morning to styling her daughteraposs hair. Katie said: It reaches all the way down to the bottom of her back now. Iaposve never seen a toddler with hair like this before. People always say to us that she is like a little Rapunzel because of how much hair she has. And then when I tell them that she is two, they just canapost believe it. Katie went to state that strangers often fail to believe Dollie is only two years old as she looks much older than her actual age due to the apossheer amount of hair she hasapos. She continued: Peopleaposs reaction is funny. But she loves her long hair and so do I. Katie expresses that her daughteraposs hair can be quite a challenge to deal with in the morning, as it tends to get very knotty. Andshe is tasked with also washing her hair, that then adds another  minutes to the  minutes she already spends styling - but admits her daughter does enjoy the pampering session. ButDollie could have her way with styling her hair, sheaposd leave it all down - something her mum just canapost allow it. She added: But I canapost let her have it down all the time because of how knotted it gets, and she sometimes gets things stuck in it. Katie admits she has enjoyed going to YouTube to watch hair tutorials to teach her new style for Dollie. And her daughter certainly makes it a more pleasurable experience as she sits ever so still through the styling. title: sweet letter written olympic hero
story: Sweet letter written to Olympic hero  years ago discovered under floorboardsA note written to Olympic bronze medallist Michael Wheeler from his mum has been found under the floorboards of his old school,  years after it was sent in Students at Taunton School say finding the letter has been exciting Image: Taunton School   SWNSByZahna EklundAudience writer:,  Dec | commentsA -year-old letter written to a would-be Olympic hero has been unearthed from under the floorboards of his old school. The note was addressed to Michael Wheeler and was from his mum – and was sent  years before he bagged the bronze medal for team GB in the xm relay at the  Melbourne Olympic Games alongside Peter Higgins, John Salisbury and Derek Johnson. Penned in , the letter was found at Taunton School in Somerset by painter and decorator Andy Budge, who was completing refurbishments on the property. He said: I was hunting around to seethere was anything there, I found a few old coins and stamps, then I found the letter. Get the news you want straight to your inbox.for a Mirror newsletter here. Someone  might have seen an old piece of paper and put it in the bin but I’m interested in history, so I was curious. aposaposIt made me feel quite sentimental to think that this letter is part of the history of the school. Michael’s first three years at Taunton School were during World War II, during air raids and food shortages. And the letter sees his mum explain that she had to travel to  dferent shops to find him the perfect Scouts unorm. It reads: In very great haste. Darling Mick, Hope you are pleased with your parcel. I went to  shops to get the scout’s unorm. If too long, matron will no doubt alter them for you.  Longing to see you Paddington th. All my love Mummy xx During his time at Taunton School, Michael broke several school records in running events, then went on to compete internationally, propelling him towards Olympic success. Taunton School archivist John Brown said: We dusted off the old registers and it was certain that the boy in the letter is the young athlete who went on to compete in the Olympics. Michael Wheeler was one of the best athletes Taunton School has ever produced. The letter has even been helpful in teaching current Taunton School pupils about World War II, as -year-old Ellie Onesti said it was “really exciting” to learn how dferent school le would have been in Michael’s day. She said: “We learnt about the war in school recently so it’s really exciting to see this letter. It was written not long after the war when Michael was the same age as me, le for him would have been very dferent. Michael retired from athletics in  and went on to become a teacher, before he sadly passed away in January  at the age of .Have you got a story to share  We want to hear all about it. title: toddler playing puddles grandad ran
story: Toddler was playing in puddles when her grandad ran her over with caravan and killed herLittle Josie Gordon was on the first day of a family holiday at a campsite in Cornwall when she was killed by the caravan towed by her grandfatherJosies family was staying at a campsite in Cornwall Image: Getty Images iStockphotoByRod Minchin:,  Dec Updated:,  Dec A toddler died when she was struck by her grandparentsapos moving caravan as she jumped around playing in puddles, an inquest has heard. Little Josie Gordon, who was  months old, was on the first day of a family holiday at a campsite in Cornwall when she was killed by the caravan towed by her grandfather. Police investigators believe Josie had either been standing close to the caravan when it began moving, and was knocked down, or had put herself on the floor and was run over. The injuries to her head and chest were so severe she died almost instantaneously, despite receiving prompt medical attention. Cornwall Coroneraposs Court heard Josie and her parents, Harry Gordon and Hannah Bingham, had set off from their home on the morning of May  this year in their VW campervan. They were meeting family members, including Josieaposs grandparents, Ian and Bethan Gordon, for a week-long break on The Lizard peninsula.  In a written statement, Ms Bingham said the accident happened in a matter of seconds while Josie jumped around in the puddles in her wellies. I had a good view of everything and could see Josie was just playing in the puddles at the back of Ian and Bethanaposs caravan - she was having the time of her le, she said. It felt like the car and caravan had been moving for a couple of seconds when the caravan, moving, passed me and once it moved passed, I instantly saw Josie on the ground of the gravel track. It literally felt like seconds from seeing her in the puddle to then seeing her on the floor. I didnapost see what or how she came to be on the floor. All I saw was the car and caravan move forwards and suddenly she was on the floor. Harry shouted, aposJosieaposs on the floorapos and Ian instantly stopped the car. Harry scooped her up and I donapost think we realised how bad it was. I was just telling that mummyaposs here, and I was trying to keep her warm and I kissed her hands. I think I knew deep down she wasnapost okay, but I didnapost want to believe what I thought. Miss Bingham added: I donapost know what happened in the seconds between seeing her playing and seeing her on the ground. I wondered whether she crawled underneath the caravan to get something. Josieaposs father said as the car pulled away the caravan rocked side to side asit had run over something and then realised his daughter was on the floor. When he was told Josie had died, he said: I thought this wasnapost real. I was in total disbelief about what happened. In a statement, Josieaposs grandfather said he had checked his wing mirrors before pulling away and did not see anything or feel any impact. I was moving forward and only had been doing that for a few seconds when I heard Harry shout, aposJosieaposs been run over by the caravanapos, he said. Mr Gordon said in a subsequent victim personal statement that the death of his only grandchild had left him with painful remorse and constant grief. Pc Scott Robinson, who investigated the accident, told the inquest that due to Josieaposs height she was probably not seen by her grandfather. Josie has been knocked under the caravan and become injured when the caravan began to move over her, he said. It is also possible that Josie had no perception of danger at the time the caravan was stationary and had put herself under the caravan, becoming injured when the caravan began to move. I am not able to say from the evidence which of these scenarios is most likely. A post-mortem examination found she had suffered fatal head and chest injuries consistent with being run over by the wheel of the caravan. Andrew Cox, senior coroner for Cornwall, recorded a conclusion Josie had died as a result of a road traffic collision. By any description this is a tragic set of circumstances and I cannot begin to imagine how dficult this has been for all the members of the family, particularly Josieaposs parents, he said. It seems to me the two alternatives put forward by Pc Robinson are entirely sensible and I accept one of them is likely to be the cause for this incident. Tragically, Mr Gordon has not seen Josie and she hasnapost appreciated the danger of the situation and while playing innocently this tragedy has unfolded in a matter of a few seconds. I have only the deepest sympathy for all those involved in this incident. In a statement issued after the inquest, Josieaposs parents said: Josie was a happy, vibrant, beautul force of nature, whose le was tragically taken in the worst of circumstances. She will be eternally cherished by all of us and, in particular, her loving parents. The sunshine she brought to all our lives will last forever.
